TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) left Australia on 18 September to attend the United Nations General Assembly in New York. PETITION.TITLE: Copyright
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Copyright
To the Honourable the President, and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Copyright Act as amended by the Copyright Amendment Act, 1980, places unnecessary restrictions on the education systems.
That all photocopying and videorecording used exclusively for education purposes should be exempted from the provisions of the Copyright Act.
That any amendments to the Copyright law which affect the education system should not be made operative during an academic year.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Division of Sydney East respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to downgrade Postal and Mail services throughout Australia, will place in jeopardy the existing services and the security of the mails by:
downgrading a large number of official post offices;
reducing the number of post offices open for business during the lunch period;
reducing the number of street posting boxes;
delaying telegrams by reducing the number of delivery offices;
downgrading post office services by employing untrained and unqualified staff; and
using private contractors for mail cartage.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission implementing any plan which will downgrade the Postal and Mail services of the citizens of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the decision of the government to terminate the Community Youth Support Scheme from October 31, 1981, will deny unemployed youth the significant skills and support that the Scheme provided. This will result in greater hardship and alienation of these young people from society.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reconsider the closure of the Community Youth Support Scheme and continue its funding in recognition of its significant contribution to the welfare of unemployed youth.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MASON
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, contingent on the President proceeding to the placing of business on any day, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Mason moving a motion relating to the order of business on the Notice Paper.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask whether he recalls this statement by the Prime Minister on 9 July 1975:

QUESTION.PARA: Ten per cent or even 50 per cent of the truth is as good a way of misleading this Parliament and the Australian people as a downright lie.

Was that criterion applied in August 1978 when the Minister, as a result of the application of that criterion, got his job as Leader of the Opposition in the Senate? Is that still the standard of conduct which applies to Ministers of this Government?

TALK.START.PARA: —Frankly, I do not understand the second part of the question. Perhaps by way of supplementary question that could be explained. I would be happy to respond to it.

—As I understand it, the Government applied that criterion in removing Senator Withers from the Ministry in August 1978. That part of the question related to a casual vacancy which arose in the position of Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask: Was that criterion applied then and is it still the standard of the Government?

—Basically, the reason for my confusion was, as Senator Button will know, that he asked about the 'Leader of the Opposition in the Senate'. I was not in a position to refer to criteria regarding the integrity of the Leader of the Opposition. The fact is, as I understand it, that the Prime Minister in his then capacity in July 1975 made statements regarding integrity. Those statements have been adhered to and will continue to be adhered to. The unfortunate circumstances relating to the Royal Commission of Inquiry on Matters in Relation to Electoral Redistribution are known to the Senate and I do not think they are to be canvassed. The findings of the Royal Commission are known and therefore the matter is one on which the Senate is fully informed. I do not wish to comment any further.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: POLICE FORCES: RETIREMENTS DUE TO ILL HEALTH

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services to a recent report by the Secretary of the Victorian Police Association, Inspector Tom Rippon, alleging that the number of police officers who have left the Victorian Police Force because of ill health has increased more than twenty-fold in the last 20 years and that more than 80 per cent of the retirements were related directly to job stress. Is the Minister aware of any similar situation existing in the Australian Federal Police and, if such a situation does exist, what steps are being taken to combat it? If such a condition of extreme job stress is not apparent at present what, if any, programs with suitable back-up services can be introduced to ensure that this condition is kept to a minimum?

—At present there is considerable interest in the matter of stress as it relates to people in various areas, including those holding office in the Parliament and in the Public Service. I am aware that the number of retirements from the Commonwealth Public Service came under notice within the last four or five years. Observations were made then about the increasing number of retirements due to invalidity, and about the different incidences of retirements as between regions. The important matter raised by Senator Bonner is one that has been under attention for some time but not in any organised way. I am not aware of the remarks of Inspector Tom Rippon concerning the Victorian Police; nor am I aware of the basis on which he states that retirements due to invalidity have increased by 20 times. I will refer the question to the Minister for Administrative Services and seek an answer to the matters raised by Senator Bonner.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PUBLIC FUNDING OF ELECTION CAMPAIGNS AND MINISTERS' LEGAL COSTS

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Acting Treasurer to a motion passed by the House of Representatives last Tuesday. That motion recommended that the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act be amended to take into account election funding when examining relativities between the States for revenue sharing. It also recommended that the Federal Government investigate the possibility of immediately reducing general revenue grants to States which adopt election funding by amounts equal to those spent by State governments for the funding of political parties. The intention of the motion was to deprive the State of New South Wales of Commonwealth funding because of that State's public funding of elections. I ask the Minister whether, in view of this expression of opinion by the House of Representatives, the Government has considered amending the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act to take into account taxpayers' funding of private legal expenses incurred by Ministers of the Crown? If so, will Queensland residents be penalised if the Queensland Government pays the private legal costs of a Queensland Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has not given any consideration to the matter raised by Senator Colston. I am not aware of the resolution that was passed in the House of Representatives regarding funding of political parties or of a recommendation to the Commonwealth Grants Commission relating to that matter. Neither has any consideration been given to whether grants to States ought to be adjusted if legal expenses are paid for Ministers, former Ministers or former Prime Ministers. Those matters do not warrant comment at this time because no consideration has been given to them by the Government. Nor would I suggest that there is great substance in the suggestions that have been made. However, I will take note of the question and perhaps, if some consideration is given to it, will advise the Senate accordingly.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to the current strike in the central Queensland coal fields which is now in its third month. Will the Minister advise the decrease in the coal tonnages because of the strike and the effect that decrease could be having on our export markets? Will the Minister advise also how many other people employed on the coal fields have been stood down because of the strike action by members of the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union and what amount has been lost in wages by those workers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the current strike affecting seven mines in the central Queensland coal fields, which has been going on for some time and which is of concern to the Government, has caused great disruption to production and future exports. I understand that the strike is being caused by one union, the AMWSU, and has led to the stand-down of a number of members of other unions. Last week in the House of Representatives the Deputy Prime Minister responded to a question from the Leader of the Opposition and made the point that if the Opposition was concerned about helping Australian export industries it might play a more constructive role in endeavouring to improve our industrial relations.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been advised that the loss of production caused by the dispute will prevent the shipment of some 2.5 million tonnes of export coal, with a consequent loss in export revenue of $125m. Furthermore, the Commonwealth and Queensland governments either have forgone or will forgo some $54m in lost taxes, duties and so on, even if the strike ends immediately, and the wage loss to industry employees is now in excess of $4m. The dispute was before the Coal Industry Tribunal late last week. A further hearing before the Tribunal was to have taken place on Friday. I have no up to date information on the outcome of that inquiry. I do not have information either on the precise number of employees stood down, which I think was part of the question asked by the honourable senator. I will seek advice on the position following the Friday meeting of the Coal Industry Tribunal and also try to get the precise figures for the honourable senator.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: WORKERS COMPENSATION AND THIRD PARTY INSURANCE

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Treasurer. It refers to a report in today's Business Age, attributed to Ian Davis in Canberra, and headed 'Canberra may curb States on insurance'. The article states:

QUESTION.PARA: The Federal Government is considering restricting the operations of the State Governments and their government insurance offices in the general insurance industry.

The Government is to discuss with the general insurance industry whether it wishes to see restrictions placed on the operations of State Governments in setting workers' compensation and compulsory third party insurance premiums.

Is the report correct? If so, what are the reasons for the Government wishing to place restrictions on State governments participating in the writing of insurance? Is the Minister aware that the South Australian State Government Insurance Commission does not set the premiums for third party insurance in that State, but that the premiums are in fact set by the Third Party Insurance Premiums Committee, which is chaired by Mr Justice Sangster, whose reputation for impartiality is second to none? Finally, is the Minister aware that all private insurance companies opted out of writing third party compulsory insurance in South Australia of their own volition and not at the direction of the State Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have not seen the report referred to by Senator McLaren, but I will seek information on whether there is any basis for it, with regard to the State governments' insurance arrangements, or any change which may have been the basis for the report concerned. I am aware of the differing arrangements in the various States with regard to third party insurance and other insurance, and if there is any basis for the report or if any information is available I will see that Senator McLaren is advised.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations and refers to the marine engineers' strike that has held up Australian shipping for weeks. In particular, as a consequence, South Australians are urgently concerned about supplies of petrol. The shortage of petrol in South Australia is now so severe that it is no longer on public sale. Severe petrol restrictions are pending in New South Wales also. What has been the outcome of yesterday's statements by the Minister for Transport, Mr Hunt? What initiatives are being taken by Mr Viner? What is the Government's assessment of the situation now that yesterday's Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission talks failed to end the strike?

—The strike mentioned by the honourable senator is, of course, one which is extremely serious and which is bearing heavily on a number of States, in particular his own State of South Australia. I know that the Minister for Industrial Relations has been in contact with a number of unions with respect to this matter and that it has been before the Arbitration Commission. I will seek an up to date report from the Minister for the honourable senator as soon as possible.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry taken note of the latest Bureau of Agricultural Economics index of prices which shows farm inflation running at 14.5 per cent in the 12 months to June 1981? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the Government's estimate of the inflationary effect that the sales tax increases announced in the Budget will have on farm costs and what other effects the Budget is likely to have on the inflation rate for farmers?
—I will refer that question to the Minister for Primary Industry and get a reply.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Will the Australian Government take the initiative in the current United Nations session in sponsoring the Greek Cypriot boundary formula announced last week in London as the basis of a lasting peace in Cyprus?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware that both communities have tabled proposals relating to problems facing Cyprus at recent sessions of the intercommunal talks. It would be inappropriate for the Government to comment on these proposals when they are being discussed by the two communities at the talks. The Government continues to believe that any lasting settlement of the Cyprus question can be reached only by taking into account the legitimate interests and concerns of both the Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot communities. The intercommunal talks provide the most appropriate forum for these concerns to be taken into account. As the intercommunal talks are continuing, it remains to be seen how the United Nations General Assembly will handle the Cyprus question this year. It will be recalled that last year consideration of the Cyprus item was deferred in view of the recommencement of the intercommunal talks. I am aware of Senator Mulvihill's interest in this matter and as soon as there is any further information I will see that he has advice about it.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I take it from the Minister's response that the Australian Government is not going to follow blindly the fixation of the United States with North Atlantic Treaty Organisation powers and the role of Turkey in that area. In effect what the Minister has just said means that we will make an objective evaluation, free of super-power pressures.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not want to add to what I have already said. I would not want to comment on the proposals while they are being discussed by the two communities at the talks. I think Senator Mulvihill can be assured that Australia always weighs carefully proposals such as the one we are discussing at present and that if decisions are needed to be taken by the Australian Government they will be taken with a careful evaluation of all the matters that need consideration.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH HEADS OF GOVERNMENT MEETING: POLICE EXERCISES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. How many Victorian police recruits have been injured in unarmed combat and other exercises carried out in preparation for the security arrangements surrounding the forthcoming Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting? What was the nature of their injuries?

—I have no knowledge that any police have been injured at all. If Senator Primmer has that information he might let me have it. But, in any case, I will ask the Prime Minister whether he can secure from the Premier of Victoria any relevant information. If there is such information I will let Senator Primmer have it. The fact is that in the weeks immediately ahead we are going to have in Australia one of the most significant world conferences. It is a fact that there is a risk of violence and therefore there is a need for extraordinary police precautions to safeguard against that violence. If, indeed, in any exercises some police had been injured that would be sad. But the exercises are part of the process of keeping the law and keeping the peace in a country where we abhor violence. We will attempt to see that it does not occur.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to the referendum held in New South Wales on Saturday in which an overwhelming number of people supported the compulsory disclosure of parliamentarians' interests. With the wisdom of hindsight, does the Minister not now think that it might have been advisable for the present Government at least to have adopted the recommendations of the report of the Bowen Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest? In view of the Government's inaction in that the Government has failed to honour its promise to have a debate in the Senate on this issue and has failed to implement the provisions of the Bowen report other than in a private arrangement between the Prime Minister and his Ministers, will the Government now take into account the expressed wish of the people of New South Wales and perhaps consider having a referendum on the issue?
—Far from inaction, it was this Government which set up an objective and expert inquiry known as the Bowen Committee of Inquiry into the pecuniary interests of Ministers and members.
—That is not true, and you know it.

—I repeat that this Government, the Fraser Government, set up the Bowen Committee of Inquiry. That is a matter of fact. It is no use the Leader of the Opposition saying: 'That is not true'. It happens to be fundamentally true. It is equally true that the Government has adopted the provisions of the Bowen Committee report and has applied them to Ministers. It is in the process of having discussions at this moment to extend those provisions to members of Parliament. I take it from Senator Button's question that, in fact, the Opposition will support the Bowen Committee. We will be bringing into this Parliament in due course recommendations for the implementation, for members as distinct from Ministers, of the remaining provisions of the Bowen Committee report. Incidentally, from my recollection, the Bowen Committee did not advocate disclosure by way of a register. In fact, it suggested otherwise. The procedures for the implementation of the Bowen Committee recommendations are being looked at at this moment.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I refer to that part of the Minister's answer which suggests that the Fraser Government was responsible for initiating the concept of public disclosure of members' private interests. I ask the Minister: Is it not a fact that in 1974 the Labor Government set up a joint party committee of this Parliament in relation to the disclosure of members' private interests? Is it not a fact that that committee reported unanimously and that the decisions and recommendations of that committee, which were in favour of full disclosure and a public register, were too hot for the Fraser Government to handle and because of that the Bowen Committee was established?

—Of course, that question bears no relation to and does not support in any way the interjection of Senator Button which was: 'That is not true'. I repeat emphatically and without qualification that the Fraser Government set up the Bowen Committee of Inquiry into pecuniary interests.
—That is not what you said.

—That is what I said and that is what Hansard will bear out. It is a fact that during the Whitlam Government's term of office it had some inquiries. As I understand it, it did not implement their recommendations. Rather than the matter being too hot to handle, this Government set up the inquiry, has received the report and is proceeding to implement its recommendations.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs to the statement made by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs on 27 August in which the Minister stated that all young people involved in the Community Youth Support Scheme would be invited to contact the Commonwealth Employment Service for a special interview and that the purpose of the interview would be to provide a young person with counselling and advice as to the program best suited to the job desired. Can the Minister confirm that to this stage the response to these invitations has been disappointing? If there are CYSS participants who are unable to take up Government sponsored employment training opportunities for reasons of lack of self-confidence and personal motivation, are they not equally unlikely, for the same reasons, to avail themselves of the offered formal interviews at CES centres? Therefore, is the Minister prepared to consider altering the current arrangements to allow such interviews by the Commonwealth Employment Service to take place at CYSS project centres in an informal atmosphere?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have no information with regard to the response by young people to the invitation to avail themselves of an opportunity for an interview. I do not know what the response has been but I could seek that information from the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. As far as the latter part of the question is concerned, and Senator Hill's suggestion that there might be some young people who would wish to have an informal interview or discussion about their employment prospects, I will convey that suggestion to the Minister and see what reaction I get.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry and arises from the Deputy Prime Minister's latest attempt to defend his colleague Mr Sinclair, in which he claimed that the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations had been slothful and inept with its inquiries and report on the Australian Dairy Corporation. I ask: Will the Deputy Prime Minister and the Minister for Primary Industry therefore apply their superior diligence and perspicacity, as well as the resources of government, to tracking down the millions of dollars paid into overseas bank accounts which the Senate Committee was unable to trace?

—I had not heard the criticism of the Senate Committee referred to by the honourable senator in his question. I thought they were the sorts of words of criticism that might have been addressed to Senator Walsh for his speech in the Senate when the Committee's report was brought down, and in particular his version of what paragraph 9.38 of the report meant. In any event, the report deals in part with questions as to the moneys which were paid by way of rebate, and the disposal of part of those moneys is, I think, dealt with in the report the Senate Committee has put down. In particular, as I recall it, the Third Schedule of the report deals with an agreement with respect to the disposal of some of those moneys. However, I will examine in more detail the question which has been asked by the honourable senator and see whether the matters he has raised warrant further consideration by the Minister and a further reply.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Has the Government's attention been drawn to the recent Australian Council of Trade Unions decision concerning the export live sheep industry, which last year involved 5.6 million sheep and produced approximately $163m? Has account been taken of the effects of such a decision on unions other than the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union? I refer to the Australian Workers Union and its loss of 4 million or 5 million sheep a year for shearing, and the Transport Workers Union, which is involved in carting, and so on. If the decision were to be implemented, is any information available which would indicate that there is a payable market for the extra quantity of carcass meat suggested, or would it be expected to result in a substitution of live sheep from other countries? With the current lower slaughter numbers and the reduced throughput per slaughterman per day, what number of extra slaughtermen is it envisaged that the carrying out of this very dubious proposal may produce, as against the jobs it would cost?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator raised in his question matters which have been subject to some debate around Australia for some years now. The creation of fresh markets for Australian beasts through live export has been of great satisfaction to primary producers because it has provided markets to them in circumstances where markets otherwise might not have been available. I suppose the honourable senator's question relates to the most recent round of matters which have been raised. The Government's attention has been drawn to the ACTU resolution requesting the Government to restrict live sheep exports to a one for one, live sheep to mutton carcass ratio to all market countries. I think that advice was received direct from the ACTU, but as yet the Government has not received any advice from the ACTU as to how that resolution might be implemented. Just last month, prior to that decision, the Minister for Primary Industry met with an ACTU delegation led by the ACTU President, Mr Cliff Dolan. Following an undertaking given at that time, he will give a detailed response to the issues that the delegation raised with him.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the other points raised by the honourable senator in his question are concerned, it would be understood by him, I think, that freshly killed meats are still preferred by the majority of the population in our main market area, the Middle East. Also, the market for chilled and frozen lamb, beef and buffalo meat, and especially for poultry, has expanded significantly. Any move to restrict live sheep supplies may well result in a net loss for Australia as Middle East markets move to alternative meat or livestock supplies from other countries. World mutton markets are not currently buoyant and it is likely that any additional mutton available would have a depressing effect on the whole market, including sheep prices.

The honourable senator also raised the question of jobs in the industry. As far as that is concerned, the live sheep trade has generated new jobs in transport, shearing, manufacture of pellet fodder and preparation of sheep for export. Restriction of live sheep exports would result in loss of jobs in these areas, with no guarantee of a corresponding increase in jobs in meatworks.

It is not possible by action in Australia to dictate what form of meat will be imported by countries to which we are able to export. For that reason it is not a matter of the Government simply making decisions as to ratios or anything else. It is a matter of responding in the most sensible way possible to the markets which are available to our primary producers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. When will this Liberal Government make some firm decisions in favour of Australia? I refer to the recent announcement that the Shell Company of Australia Ltd considered this an inopportune time to increase the Australian equity and the Government's meek acceptance of this outrageous decision. The other matter is the case of Borg-Warner Australia Ltd, where many workers are in danger of losing their jobs because of the Government's proposed legislation. Will the Leader tell the Senate when this Government will consider Australia and Australians before some multinationals which come here primarily for a quick buck and to bleed the country dry in the process?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question may qualify for an Oscar for histrionics but not for facts.
—You would be the best judge of that around this place.

—Yes, indeed; I accept that I am a good judge because the theatre that faces me indulges in histrionics every day. The fact is that, as demonstrated by such things as reports from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, this Government has so much put Australia first that we are pacesetters in the development of economic stability. That has been recognised by objective arbiters from abroad. If Senator Elstob had wanted to read further in the Shell company statement he would have seen that there was an undertaking by Shell to pay heavy regard to Australian participation in further developments.

ANSWER.PARA: We have established the Foreign Investment Review Board. It has set a minimum standard of 50 per cent Australian equity and participation in resources development. That in itself is highly significant and we have maintained it. We propose to go on maintaining it. We are attracting very considerable Australian investment. By the whole of our approaches, whether to nationals or multinationals, we are endeavouring to ensure that the development of Australia increases the real standard of living of Australians. In a year in which inflation ran at 8.8 per cent, the increase in average real wages ran at over 14 per cent. Therefore, there was a real increase in real wages for most Australians.

The question of industry and its protection is one that is under review by this Government. I am astonished at this question because from time to time I have heard Labor senators and Labor members seek lower protection. Who more than the Australian Labor Party would stand convicted of lower protection? It was the Whitlam Government which cut tariffs 25 per cent across the board and, in a space of six months, put 110,000 people out of employment. It is a strange question to be put to this Government by a member of a party which cut tariffs arbitrarily and brutally disemployed people in Australia. I have to say to Senator Elstob: 'Physician, cure thyself'.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer to the investigation proposed by the Review of Commonwealth Functions into the purposes and activities of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies in relation to the legislation under which it was created. Has that inquiry commenced and, if not, when will it be undertaken?

—It is true that the Review of Commonwealth Functions decided that there should be an external review of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies. The Institute had intended to undertake an internal review, but a separate review is now to be conducted by the Government. It was necessary to find someone of appropriate eminence to investigate what is, after all, an academic institution engaged in academic pursuits as they relate to Aboriginal advancement. It has taken us some time to identify an appropriate person, but I can advise the honourable senator that Professor R. J. Walsh, who is Dean of the Faculty of Medicine in the University of New South Wales, has agreed to undertake this investigation. Professor Walsh is a Fellow of the Academy of Sciences and an eminent academician. He has been Dean of the Faculty of Medicine for some years. He is a professor of human genetics. He conducted the inquiry into the crown of thorns starfish for the Commonwealth and has served on a number of Commonwealth advisory bodies. His administrative expertise and experience and his academic standing will be ideally suited for the task in hand. I understand that the professor has academic commitments at the moment but that he will be able to undertake the study from the beginning of 1982, possibly starting the investigation in January or February next year.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of a resolution passed at the ninety-eighth plenary session meeting of the United Nations General Assembly requesting member states to cease any cultural collaboration with South Africa and appealing to writers, artists, musicians and other personalities to boycott South Africa? Does the Government realise that Australian Actors Equity has, in accordance with the United Nations policy, excluded the sale of television programs to South Africa from its collective agreements? Will the Government, in line with its policy on South Africa, adhere to the United Nations' resolution and inform the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations of its opposition to the sale of programs to South Africa, or does the Government want the members of Actors Equity to make direct representations to the heads of government attending the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting to get their support for Commonwealth endorsement of United Nations' policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I did see the comment of Actors Equity members about their attitude with regard to the sale of programs to South Africa. I am not aware of whether it was drawn to the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I will see that the question asked by Senator Childs is drawn to the Minister's attention and seek a response on the matters that were raised.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH HEADS OF GOVERNMENT MEETING: VIP AIRCRAFT

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Prime Minister, or perhaps it should be addressed to the Minister for Defence because it relates to VIP aircraft. Is the Minister able to say who will be entitled to travel in, and what criteria will apply to, VIP aircraft during the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting? What is the anticipated cost of the use of VIP aircraft during and immmediately after the Meeting for carrying heads of state around Australia?

—There are of course guidelines for the use of VIP aircraft and the carriage of persons in them. Those guidelines have, I think, been consistent under both this Government and the previous Whitlam Government. They are well known. I have no doubt that they will basically apply for the future. Senator Townley has asked specifically about costs associated with CHOGM. I will have to direct the questions to the appropriate authorities and seek a reply. There is a fallacy in relation to this whole matter of asking about costs. The aircraft are used in the training and navigational training of members of the Royal Australian Air Force. As the honourable senator would know as an aviator himself, the air crews have to achieve a certain number of flying hours. Therefore it is best that they get those hours doing a job rather than on ordinary training. The general public should understand that this is not a matter of arbitary cost. The aircraft are doing an essential job for the RAAF. I will seek information on the matter raised by the honourable senator and let him know.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is it a fact that a minute from the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Viner, which was presented to Cabinet in May of this year, expressed satisfaction with the progress of the case for the deregistration of the Builders Labourers Federation as prepared by the Minister's predecessor, Mr Peacock? If this is so, why did the Minister inform the House of Representatives and one of its Estimates committees that the case was still incomplete and unsatisfactory? Does the Minister not concede that a case of misrepresentation could be made in respect of one of these two areas?

—This is the first time that I have been asked about what happened in Cabinet. —I direct my question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Does the feasibility study for a uranium enrichment plant presently being conducted by a group representing Peko-Wallsend Ltd, Western Mining Corporation Ltd, the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Limited, and CSR Ltd include a social impact study?

—The present study relates basically to whether Australia would have the competence to carry out a uranium enrichment process; that is, to take yellow cake and enrich it. The study also seeks the best existing technology-whether a particular type of centrifuge, gaseous diffusion or chemical exchange-and, consistent with and related to that, whether there are markets available in the world for enriched uranium. The Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia has said basically that Australia has the capacity to carry out such a process and that there will be markets beyond 1990. It is seeking to determine the best technologies and shortly will make a recommendation as to the preferred technology holder. As to the question of a social impact statement, the Ranger uranium inquiry looked at the whole question of uranium. A considerable volume of knowledge exists throughout the world about the enrichment process. A number of plants already exist. If a decision were made in Australia to set up a uranium enrichment process, two undertakings would be necessary once the location had been determined-an environmental impact statement and, associated with that, a social impact statement. This is fundamentally a technology and marketing situation and a measurement of Australia's capacity in that regard. Once the report is to hand, which should be at some time next year, if a decision is made to pursue it, the question of the location of such a plant will come into consideration, and all of the necessary protective mechanisms will be put into effect. I am bound to say that there is available to us a considerable body of expert evidence on the whole of the nuclear cycle and that great experience exists around the world on the enrichment of uranium.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

DEBATE.TITLE: GOVERNMENT CLOTHING FACTORY, COBURG AND GOVERNMENT ORDNANCE FACTORY, BENDIGO

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On 26 August 1981 the Senate referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for investigation and report the Government's decision to sell the Australian Government Clothing Factory at Coburg and the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo. These decisions were announced in the report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions. The procedures for disposing of the factories have already been commenced by the Government. It is abundantly clear that if the decisions are to be reviewed, then the review should take place immediately. To delay a review would unnecessarily prolong the state of uncertainty in which all those people affected by the decisions find themselves. The Committee and indeed all honourable senators are aware of the high degree of concern over the decision felt by those affected.

SPEECH.PARA: The basic statement I wish to make to the Senate today is that the Committee is unable to undertake an inquiry into the decision at this time because of the pressure of the work load with which we are already faced. As you are aware, Mr President, since October 1977, the Committee has had the responsibility for the continuing oversight of the financial and administrative affairs or undertakings of Commonwealth statutory authorities generaly. We have produced four reports on this subject and a fifth is currently in an advanced draft stage. A considerable amount of work remains to be done on the fifth report before it can be presented to the Senate.

In addition, there are a large number of other matters currently referred to the Committee, primarily involving late annual reports which have been presented by authorities and some follow-up inquiries arising from Estimates committees. The Committee's investigations into these late annual reports can involve varying degrees of activity but can sometimes be a very substantial undertaking as they are sometimes merely a surface indication of very deep structural or operational problems. For example, our investigations of the late reports presented by the Australian Wheat Board have involved the Committee in a full scale inquiry into that authority's accounting system and its accountability. The Wheat Board's financial statements are still subject to qualification by the Auditor-General and consequently require the Committee's attention. In addition to these current references the Committee has in recent months been preparing for several major future inquiries on the completion of the current inquiries.

If the Committee were to commence an inquiry into the sale of the factories, the work involved would be substantial. We could expect submissions from all parties involved; that is, the Department, the factories themselves, factory employees, local interest groups in Coburg and Bendigo and any private enterprise groups interested in the purchase of the factories. A large number of public hearings would be involved and a visit to the factories by the Committee would be essential. Therefore, if the Committee were to commence this inquiry it would fully occupy us until well into early 1982. We would therefore have to postpone work on all other references until then.

For these reasons the Committee does not see its way clear to commence an immediate inquiry into the Government's decision to sell the factories but reiterates that any such inquiry should be conducted as a matter of urgency. If the Senate is of the opinion that the matter should be pursued, then to enable it to be conducted expeditiously it may wish to consider the establishment of a small select committee which could report in the near future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Button moving the following motion: That-

(a) the resolution of the Senate on 26 August 1981 referring to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations the Government's decision to sell the Government Clothing Factory at Coburg and the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo be rescinded;
(b) a Select Committee be established on the future of the Government Clothing Factory at Coburg and the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo;
(c) the Select Committee report to the Senate by the first sitting day in November 1981 on the future of the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo; and
(d) the composition and powers of the Select Committee be contained in a subsequent resolution.

The reasons for the suspension of Standing Orders I think are quite clear. They have emerged from the debate which has already taken place on this matter. They are very clearly expressed in the statement which has just been brought down by Senator Peter Rae. His statement reads:

It is abundantly clear that if the decisions are to be reviewed, then the review should take place immediately. To delay a review would unnecessarily prolong the state of uncertainty in which all those people affected by the decisions find themselves.

I submit that it is not the business of this Parliament to leave people in this commuinity in a state of uncertainty about matters which relate to their livelihood. It is important that the Standing Orders be suspended so that this committee can be established as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Button's comments. I believe there is some urgency for a decision on this matter, particularly insofar as the Bendigo Ordnance Factory is concerned. I support the appointment of a select committee, rather than the reference of the matter to a standing committee, so that a decision, at least one which applies to the Bendigo Ordnance Factory, can be expedited.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Establishment of Select Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That-

(a) the resolution of the Senate of 26 August 1981 referring to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations the Government's decision to sell the Government Clothing Factory at Coburg and the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo be rescinded;
(b) a Select Committee be established on the future of the Government Clothing Factory at Coburg and the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo;
(c) the Select Committee report to the Senate by the first sitting day in November 1981 on the future of the Ordnance factory at Bendigo; and
(d) the composition and powers of the Select Committee be contained in a subsequent resolution.

The purpose of this motion has been well canvassed in the Senate in the last two or three weeks. It was canvassed first when the Senate referred the matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. The Committee, having met and considered that reference, concluded and was properly led to conclude, first of all that it might be appropriate to establish a select committee if the Senate was of that opinion, and secondly, that any inquiry conducted by the select committee should be conducted expeditiously. It is a matter of public notoriety that the proposed sale of the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo and the Government Clothing Factory at Coburg is a matter of Government decision. The purpose of this proposed inquiry by the Senate is not so much to say whether we agree or disagree with that decision but to deal with the vast range of indecisions which have arisen since the handing down of the report of the ministerial Review of Commonwealth Functions, which started this whole matter.

I illustrate this point by reference to the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo, with which I am personally fairly familiar. The Ordnance Factory employs some 600 people, of whom in excess of 200 are tradesmen. It employs quite a large number of apprentices. There is great concern about the ramifications of the decision to sell the Ordnance Factory amongst not only the work force at the factory but also the people of Bendigo generally. As in any town of that size, the employment ramifications of an industry of that size for the whole town are significant. For example, the Bendigo Ordnance Factory trains close to 100 apprentices a year. Those apprentices are trained not only for the purposes of the factory itself but also to some extent for the benefit of the industry generally in Bendigo.

Since the decision of the ministerial Review of Commonwealth Functions there has been great concern amongst the employees of the factory and generally in Bendigo in relation to this issue. Without embarking upon any ideological discussion of the desirability of the sale or otherwise at this stage, there are two, to use that dreadful word, scenarios: Firstly, the factory is sold; or secondly, it is not sold. If it is sold the very strong impression amongst people at the Ordnance Factory, and indeed amongst businessmen who have shown some interest in the factory, is that it is likely to be sold as an asset-stripping exercise. The consequences for the economy of the city of Bendigo if that takes place are very extensive. There is a lot of concern about the future employment prospects, if that takes place, of the people currently employed at the Bendigo Ordnance Factory.

Assuming, on the other hand, that the Bendigo Ordnance Factory is not sold, then there is considerable concern that because of the cloud, as it were, that has been over its future for some time it will be less successful than it has been in the past in tendering for various engineering works. There is also a very big question about continuity of government work for the Ordnance Factory. So, with either possibility, there is concern about the impact on the economy of Bendigo in respect of the future of that factory. Sold or not sold, similar concerns now arise. It is those matters in particular which it is hoped that a Senate select committee would inquire into in the hope of relieving some of the concern which exists in a city such as Bendigo. I use that as an illustration of the importance of establishing this committee and the important function which a select committee of the Senate can perform in relation to a very real economic and social problem for that city.

In a sense different considerations arise in relation to the clothing factory at Coburg but they are still factors relating to the generation of uncertainty about future employment, the operations of that factory in terms of its defence significance, and so on. But the basic question again relating to uncertainty is the question of future employment. It is for those reasons that I commend this motion to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add one brief matter. I said in my earlier statement most of what I wish to say. I should like to add, so that it is known, that the honourable member for Bendigo, Mr Bourchier, was one of those who expressed to me in very firm terms the degree of urgency which exists in having the matter clarified. He has expressed also his concern about any question of delay. That was a matter that I did report to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. It was one of the considerations which led to it reaching the conclusions which are set out in the statement I made earlier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be opposing this motion for reasons which are, in general, in accord with the views expressed in the statement put down by Senator Peter Rae with respect to the problems of delaying the review and thus unnecessarily prolonging a state of uncertainty. That is reflected in the comments that Senator Peter Rae has just made to the Senate on the views of the local member for the area. At the same time, the problem which the Senate faces is one which is worth noting, that is, just how much committee activity the Senate can undertake at any time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations might be thought to be the most appropriate Senate vehicle for this sort of exercise. But, as has been pointed out by the Committee, through its Chairman, in fact it has a work load which precludes it undertaking the work in the time that everyone agrees is appropriate, namely, as soon as possible. I have little doubt that similar problems are faced by other Senate committees. If we look at the back of the Notice Paper we find that we now have seven standing committees of the Senate, eight legislative and general purpose standing committees, eight estimates committees, three joint statutory committees and three joint committees. I think that totals 29 committees. When we consider the number of senators who are not members of the front bench of either side of the Senate, we start to realise that senators are carrying extremely heavy loads. I think that that brings out the point that there are limits on the ability of this chamber to pursue every issue of policy and every question of fact which may be of concern to honourable senators. I suggest that that is a matter which all of us in this place are going to have to bear in mind in the future.

One of the difficulties that the Senate will have is meeting what the Government would regard as a critical part of this motion, the requirement to report within a limited time. I think it is common ground around the chamber that that is desirable, and that is the reason why the Opposition, as I understand it with the support of the Australian Democrats, has proposed an inquiry which is rather shorter than the normal Senate committee inquiry. But it remains for us to find a number of senators from various parts of the chamber who will be able to give this matter the attention that will be required in the very short time that is made available by this motion.

It is the view of the Government, again in common with something said by Senator Button when he spoke to the motion a short time ago, that the sale of these properties is a matter of government decision. The decision has been taken and it is the Government's wish to proceed with the sale of those operations. The proposal for a Senate committee inquiry apparently has induced some uncertainty and some greater sense of concern in the community in which these factories operate. For that reason the Government agrees that it is desirable that the matter should be disposed of promptly. We support the appointment of a select committee on that basis and its reporting to the Senate by the first sitting day in November. Any failure to do that would exacerbate problems which were acknowledged by the Senate Committee on Finance and Government Operations, and which were acknowledged by the Opposition in putting forward this resolution.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the select committee, established by resolution of the Senate, on the future of the Government Clothing Factory at Coburg and the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo, be known as the Select Committee on the Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories.
(2) That the Committee consist of four Senators, as follows:
(a) two to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b) one to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate; and
(c) one to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats.
(3) That the Committee proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(4) That the Chairman of the Committee be appointed by and from the members of the Committee.

(5) That the Chairman of the Committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(6) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the Chairman, or the Deputy-Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(7) That two members of the Committee be necessary to constitute a meeting of the Committee for the exercise of its powers.

(8) That the Committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives, and have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations it may deem fit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Air Navigation (Charges) Amendment Bill 1981 is a machinery Bill and one which seeks to implement the professed policy of conservative governments, which was announced in 1960-that is some 21 years ago-to bring about a more relevant relationship between the costs of running the air industry in Australia by applying the principle of the user pays and of cost recovery to such an extent that the taxpayers of our country would not be required to subsidise heavily the air industry. This is a machinery Bill and as such the Opposition, having adopted a consistent attitude to amendments to air navigation charges over the years, does not intend to oppose it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill is designed to amend the Air Navigation (Charges) Act 1952 which prescribes the charges payable in respect of the use by aircraft of aerodromes, air route and airway facilities, meteorological services and search and rescue services which are maintained, operated or provided by the Commonwealth. The purpose of the Bill is to vary the rates of air navigation charges payable for aircraft operating in all sectors of the aviation industry. It is a step in the direction which ought to be supported, and is being supported, by all parties in the Senate. This piece of legislation has been on and off the legislative program for the last several weeks. One can understand, therefore, the decision of the Government to bring the legislation forward today because it is proposed that the new charges be effective from 1 October which is not much more than a week away.

The variations proposed in the rate of air navigation charges are to reduce the rates applicable to the international sector by 5 per cent; to increase the rates applicable to the domestic airline sector by 12 1/2 per cent; to increase the rates applicable to the regional airline sector by 25 per cent, and to increase the rates applicable to general aviation sectors by 20 per cent. If these proposals are acceptable to the Parliament-I am sure they will be, having read the debates which have taken place in the House of Representatives-it is estimated that revenue to be earned by the Commonwealth from air navigation charges in 1981-82 will, together with payments made in that year for 1980-81 operations, total $115.76m. This compares with the $95.89m received from air navigation charges in the preceding year, 1980-81. Further, the levels of increase proposed for the domestic airlines should have a minimal effect on air fares as they should increase airlines costs by about one per cent for regional airlines and by about 0.5 per cent for domestic trunk airlines. The impact on total costs faced by general aviation operators in that area is also expected to be minimal, although one could imagine that in some sense there will be further criticism by a number of airline operators about the proposed increased charges.

Honourable senators might be reminded that the Liberal-National Country Party Government projected in 1961 that there was a need to adopt a policy. The Government subsequently did so in its 1961 Budget for the eventual full recovery of the costs properly attributable to the air transport industry for providing and maintaining the aviation infrastructure. We are aware that in succeeding years the whole infrastructure of the airline industry has increased dramatically in terms of both construction costs and the maintenance of those new facilities. We now have an air industry which is comparable with-some will say it is better than-any other airline industry in the world. As the Australian Labor Party has said on so many occasions, I think it is proper that the general taxpayer should not be called upon to subsidise the airline industry any longer. It is a major industry and it is capable of sustaining itself. It is a very profitable industry for the main airline operators. It is very profitable from the point of view of the international airlines. It is proper, therefore, that they should pay the substantive part of the costs involved in maintaining the airline infrastructure.

Full recovery of attributable costs was first achieved in 1975-76 in respect of the international sector. While this sector has continued to be fully recovered, the rates of air navigation charges for international operations have not been varied since 1 December 1976. Further, in the 1980-81 Budget, the Government announced that overrecovery in this area should be credited to the cost recovery program and applied to the development of the aviation infrastructure generally. The Government has decided that there should be a reduction of 5 per cent in the rate of air navigation charges for international operators effective also from the date to which I referred earlier-that is, 1 October 1981. While there will be overrecovery in this sector, the Government reaffirms its 1980-81 decision on the treatment to be afforded overrecovery from this sector of the industry.

It should be noted also that the Australian charges for international operations compare more than favourably with those imposed overseas when the comparison is made on the same basis. I think we are entitled to say that the international operators have very little to complain about in relation to the way in which successive Australian governments have endeavoured to adopt a rational attitude in respect of international charges. Australia, unlike most overseas countries, imposes a composite fee which covers landing fees, parking fees, terminal air traffic control, en-route aids and services, et cetera. Overseas, these elements are often the subject of separate charges, which can be raised by different authorities, and in some cases they may vary accordingly.

Honourable senators will recall that in the 1981 airlines agreement, the Australian National Airlines Commission and the companies recognised that the Commonwealth is entitled to recover fully its infrastructure costs. That is progress, having regard to the complaints that were received years ago when governments generally set about in a bipartisan fashion to put the operations of the airlines on such a basis that the taxpayers would not be subsidising the industry. Both airlines agreed to facilitate the implementation of measures designed to achieve this objective. Their agreement was subject to the proviso that, allowing for minor variations between the years, the Commonwealth did not seek to recover more than 100 per cent of its costs. Moreover, to achieve this objective, the agreement does not limit the level of air navigation charges which the Government may impose. Of course, one has to say that the Commonwealth, in the years that it has accepted responsibility for the airline industry, has outlaid tremendous capital costs in developing the infrastructure which now makes the industry such an important part of our whole economy. The decision taken by government to increase the rates of air navigation charges for the domestic trunk airline sector by 12 1/2 per cent is in accord with the agreement and should result in a recovery rate approaching 100 per cent in 1981-82.

Last year the Government decided that there would be no change in the level of air navigation charges for both the regional airline and general aviation sectors. These charges, however, were to be reviewed in the light of the study of the general aviation sector. As honourable senators will know, the Government has not accepted the cost recovery recommendations made by that study, although the rate of charges will continue to be reviewed annually. The Government has decided to increase air navigation charges by 25 per cent and 20 per cent for the regional airline and general aviation sectors respectively. These rates of increase should result in similar rates of recovery in those sectors to those achieved in 1980-81.

Before I seek leave, with the assistance of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner), to incorporate in Hansard a table setting out the cost recovery rates in total for the years 1970-71 to 1979-80, I remind the Senate that in 1974 the then Minister for Transport, as a member of the Labor Party, sought to increase cost recovery rates generally. I remind honourable senators that in 1970-71 the rate was only 49.4 per cent from all sectors and that for the year 1974-75 the Labor Party Transport Minister, Mr Charles Jones, moved to increase that rate to achieve a recovery of 54.8 per cent so that the deficit for that year, which was a charge to the taxpayers, would be $65m. Mr Jones did not get the support of the Opposition Liberal and Country parties whose supporters were quite critical of Mr Jones's attempts to implement what in fact was a policy initiated by the conservative Government in 1961. In the House of Representatives every legislative trick in the book was pulled to create difficulties for the Labor Government in 1975. It is interesting to note the Mr Nixon, who is now under some difficulties in explaining away his lack of administrative capacity as Minister for Primary Industry, was the prime culprit in that debate. One can only say that in 1974 the conservatives were dragging the chain in respect of this very principle on which they expect, and are willingly receiving, the support of the Opposition concerning this legislation. It seems to me that if we support the principle so strongly exhibited by the Menzies administration in 1961 that the airline industry should stand on its own feet and that we should move from the very low participation by the various sectors of the airline industry in contributing to the cost of the infrastructure, it is hard to understand why such a negative attitude was taken by Mr Nixon in that period. I suppose we can only say it was part of the obstruction and the difficulties that the conservatives applied generally during the three years of the Labor Government from 1972 to 1975. Certainly we do not propose to take a dog in the manger attitude on this legislation by adopting a negative position because we support the principle that the charges should be commensurate with the cost of maintaining the airline industry properly, rationally and on a basis which is not a cost to revenue, a cost to the taxpayers of this country. The Opposition supports the legislation. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table setting out the cost recovery rates for the various sectors of the civil aviation industry for the years 1970-71 to 1979-80. The table was prepared by the appropriate authority.
