SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomas Sen A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Air Navigation (Charges) Amendment Bill. I believe there are some serious anomalies in the way these new charges have been brought into effect but because there is a deadline of 1 October for this legislation I will not be opposing it. However, I ask the Government to consider seriously the remarks I shall make with a view to considering this matter again when the charges come before the Government for further changes. The anomalies, as I perceive them, are based on both the reports of the Holcroft Inquiry-the Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares-and the Price Waterhouse Associates report on air fare charges. Both of those reports stressed that the charges made to airline tickets should be based as closely as possible to the actual costs incurred. Both Senator Gietzelt and I agree that cost recovery should be a policy adopted by this Government. I support the user pays principle, that is, the person who flies should be the one who pays the cost. As a corollary, I believe the airline industry should have some say in the way these charges are set, and that is the basis of my problem.

SPEECH.PARA: From a study of the way in which these air navigation charges have been determined I have found that a passenger who flies direct from Perth to Sydney or from Perth to Melbourne pays the same air navigation charge amount as the person who flies the same route but whose plane lands in Adelaide. To me that seems to be contrary to the spirit of the quite specific recommendations as set out in the reports of both Holcroft and Price Waterhouse Associates. If an aeroplane does not land in Adelaide on its way to Melbourne or Sydney there is no way that it could incur the costs that an aeroplane which lands in Adelaide would incur. I think the Government has been in error in applying these sorts of increases across the board without taking these matters into consideration. I hope that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Messner, will in reply give me some assurance that the Government will consider this matter when the air navigation charges are next reviewed by it so that I can be confident this matter will be looked at again.

The second matter I wish to raise is not totally relevant to the Bill before the Senate but this is probably the only opportunity I will have to make this point. I have had a very close look at the Price Waterhouse Associates report of July 1981 which I guess was mainly a report in response to the Holcroft report. After a close study of the Price Waterhouse report I found it to be full of anomalies. I trust that the Government will be establishing the independent air fares committee very soon and that when that committee is established -I believe we have had an undertaking from the Government that any future increase in air travelling costs will be decided by that committee-it will look very closely at the Price Waterhouse Associates report. It is full of qualifications. I find it quite astounding that, having regard to the number of qualifications contained in that report, the inquiry did reach the conclusions that are set out in the report. I urge the Government in the first instance to work with all possible speed to establish the independent air fares committee. When that committee is established I expect that it will treat that Price Waterhouse report with a great deal of suspicion.

I repeat that the matter that concerns me is that the increases in the air navigation charges have been applied across the board although both the Holcroft report and the Price Waterhouse report underlined the need for the charges to be as closely as possible allocated under the user pays system. I have illustrated my concern by drawing attention to the fact that if a plane flies direct from Sydney to Perth or Melbourne to Perth and does not land in Adelaide the air navigation charges factor is charged as though that plane did land in Adelaide. That is my main concern.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to take up too much of the time of the Senate on the Air Navigation (Charges) Amendment Bill 1981, but as a South Australian I feel it is incumbent on me to make some statement on air navigation charges. As anybody who has visited South Australia, and certainly anybody who resides there, knows it is a large State with a vast area inaccessible by ordinary trunk route aircraft facilities. South Australia's outback areas depend for access very largely on the general aviation industry, and it is to this section of the Air Navigation (Charges) Amendment Bill that I will pay particular attention.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned that neither the Government nor the Opposition appears to see any problems inherent in increasing charges on the general aviation industry in Australia. It was indicated in the Budget that the charges will go up. That they are not going up more is due only to the fact that the General Aviation Association (Australia) and other organisations involved in the general aviation industry protested most strongly to the Government when they became aware of the size of the increases intended to be made under the general aviation report.

It seems to me that the Bill is attacking those least able to pay and those who are doing most to develop the Australian outback and other inaccessible areas. It also seems to me that the Government's attitude, in its user pays argument in relation to airlines, and general aviation in particular, is inconsistent with its attitude to subsidies in other areas. For instance, the Commonwealth has given considerable assistance for the development of transport networks in remote areas and for the provision of all-weather road and rail links to remote areas. It is funding national highways and developmental roads in the Northern Territory to the tune of $21.1m, of which $12.3m is earmarked for national highways and developmental roads and $6.9m for local roads.

Railway transport in remote areas has also been funded to a great extent by the Commonwealth Government. For instance, it is providing $140m for the recently constructed Tarcoola to Alice Springs railway, while the proposed construction of the links from Alice Springs to Darwin and Adelaide to Crystal Brook is also receiving attention on the grounds that they will provide faster and more reliable rail travel. The Government is quite prepared to accept that the provision of the Alice Springs to Darwin railway is hard to justify on purely economic grounds and that although there are important defence reasons for its construction, the line really is regarded as a way to breathe new life and new opportunities into communities along the railway route.

The Commonwealth has also paid substantial subsidies to offset the losses incurred in the operations of the Australian National Railways, to the tune of $58.1m in 1979-80. It also provides subsidies to the operators of developmental air services. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in his election speech promised to continue such support for aviation services to remote areas. I wonder just how consistent this promise is with the increase in general aviation charges in particular and other regional air charges in general. Apparently, the Government also promised to expand its capital works program in respect of aviation facilities, particularly a $400m program to upgrade aviation facilities at Cairns, Darwin, Townsville and Norfolk Island, in addition to several metropolitan areas. One wonders therefore whether the introduction of increased air navigation charges is being used as a means, however minor, of offsetting some of the costs of this program.

It is a fallacy to assume that the majority of people involved in general aviation are wealthy doctors or farmers who therefore can afford, as other groups in the community may not be able to do, to pay the extra charges for air navigation requirements. The Government says it is imposing these charges to offset the cost of certain equipment used by aircraft at aerodromes, between aerodromes, and so on. I contend that in fact the majority of people involved in the general aviation industry have neither any interest in nor use for some of the sophisticated devices the costs of which are being put forward by the Government as the reason behind these increased charges. It is also interesting to note that things such as beacons in many other countries of the world are funded from the defence allocation, something which this country does not seem to consider necessary. Instead, the Government applies the brunt of the burden to an industry which is vitally essential to States such as South Australia and Queensland where, as I said earlier, a vast area is isolated and inaccessible by anything other than, for example, charter aircraft.

The highest proportion of users of the general aviation sector of the aviation industry are primary and rural producers; for instance, people associated with or dependent on crop dusting or tuna spotting, whose livelihoods could very well be affected by the increase in the charges. I am surprised that the National Country Party, which alleges that one of its main interests is the welfare of country people, should not be hopping mad at the increases-however slight some people may think they are-in air navigation charges for the general aviation industry. The 20 per cent increase this year may seem much less than the 604 per cent increase over five years envisaged earlier on, but it is nevertheless an increase which can be ill-afforded by a substantial part of the general aviation industry. When compared to the 12 1/2 per cent increase in the rate now to be applied to the domestic airlines sector, I suggest that it is nothing if not a direct gift to Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans Australia Airlines at the expense of the rural sector of the general aviation industry.

Areas such as South Australia, Queensland and Western Australia will not be aided in any substantial way by the fact that regional airline sectors are expected to pay rates increased by 25 per cent. I and my party are deeply concerned at the potential loss that could occur in the general aviation industry, an industry which employs over 5,500 people and which could find itself in straitened circumstances with the application of this increase. I take this opportunity to say how disappointed we are that the other parties are apparently going to combine to pass the legislation, leaving us in an extreme minority in opposing it. We feel that the needs of the agricultural and fishing industries and of people in isolated areas will not be served at all well by the increases proposed under the Air Navigation (Charges) Amendment Bill 1981. We feel that the isolation of many people in remote areas will only be increased and that the costs added to those employed or acting as employers in the general aviation industry will not be able to be borne by many of them. Perhaps it may seem to certain members of the Labor Party that it will not hurt if a specialist doctor is not able to fly from one side of South Australia to another to attend to patients, that after all it is only his practice that will suffer, and that if his costs go up that is unfortunate. However, I suggest that the patient too will suffer as a result. It may be of no interest to some honourable senators that small farmers who rely very much on the use of charter and commuter services and so on will be hard done by. It is of considerable concern to us that this is the case, and I am afraid that I can see nothing at all to commend in this Bill of the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with interest, and indeed with some agreement, to the remarks of the previous speaker, Senator Haines. However, if the people who use the airline system are not to pay and if, according to remarks of Opposition members on the sales tax legislation, we are to reduce the Government's taxation sources, I wonder where we will be at the end of the day. Over a period the policy that the user pays has been adopted in the airline system. The burden has been spread, deliberately, unevenly across the airline system. General aviation, the charter operators and the regionals have borne lower costs than could have been attributed to them. I welcome that and think it is fair enough. The international operators have borne higher costs than should have been attributed to them and that fact has been reflected in this legislation. There is to be a slight reduction in the air navigation charges that they pay. I doubt very much whether the domestic airline operators would accept the suggestion made by Senator Haines that they are being subsidised by the general aviation sector of the market. I think one could buy an argument with them on that basis at any time of the day, and indeed also with those who use domestic airlines, because air navigation charges are reflected in the fare structure.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to express a bit of concern, having spent some time as a member of the Government and, as one interested in transport, in participating in a review of the general aviation study, at the way in which charges have been attributed. It is history now that quite a few of us took exception to the report and indeed thought it was basically unfair. We put to the Government the case that it should not be proceeded with at this time. The Government accepted that case. Consequently we did not see massive increases which would have been an impost on the general aviation sector. I accept that there is a problem in the attribution of costs, but a far deeper look into the matter is needed to ensure that there is fairness.

I accept what Senator Haines has said; that a large section of the general aviation market, and some of the charter operators, do not have a great need all of the time, or even most of the time, for the navigational aids that are around the countryside. However, a lot of the aircraft coming on to the general market have at least, as well as an automatic direction finder, distance-measuring equipment. Quite a few of the later ones have VOR-very high frequency omnidirectional radio-range equipment-which means that they can use the navigational aids, particularly if they go into controlled air space. Still, it must be said that a lot of the aircraft moving around in the inland areas of Australia do not use navigational aids to a great extent and certainly not most of the time. Consideration should be taken of the fact that such aircraft are often used privately or on station properties in order to keep mustering camps going or in flying from one property to another in the every day course of business. Their pilots have very little use for navagational aids. That should be considered when imposing air navigation charges. Also, the way in which the Department of Transport has attributed those costs should be examined.

One thing that worries me, as indeed it worries the whole aviation industry, is that we have no measurement of the efficiency of the Department of Transport. It would be no news to anybody that a lot of us are concerned about the fact that when the Department of Civil Aviation was absorbed into the Department of Transport the level of efficiency slipped. Indeed many people-and I would be one-would like to see the Department of Civil Aviation re-formed as a separate department, so that it could handle the peculiarities within the airline system operating in Australia today. We do not have a measurement of efficiencies. The people we ask to pay these charges-the aircraft owners and users-are paying they think, with some justification, into a bottomless pit by a process over which they have no control whatsoever. We have not had a good look at the internal efficiency of the Department. That should be done in order to ensure that people are obtaining the best value for the dollars that are spent. We cannot expect users to pay endlessly into this bottomless pit without being given any indication that their money is being well spent. They have a legitimate complaint, one that I accept. It is about time this matter was looked at.

In Australia we have a problem, not experienced in other countries, caused by our small population. I have mentioned it before and no doubt will mention it again. Not only have we a small population but also our population is so situated around the country that we have high costs. In Queensland we have a smaller population than does Sydney or Melbourne yet we have nine jet airports which operate every day of the week, at a not insignificant cost. In addition, we have numerous airports that are up to F27 standards, and all of the others that are used every day of the week by general aviation. The operation and maintenance of those airports does not come cheaply. Yet, as I have said before, we have such a small population over which to spread the costs. Therefore, it is all the more essential that money be spent wisely and that we have a good look at the efficiency of the Department of Transport.

I take the opportunity presented by the debate on this Bill to comment briefly on some of the statements that have been made in Brisbane about the curfew. It must be said that many people, in order to grandstand or for their own political advantage, have raised a lot of controversy in Brisbane about aircraft that are capable of flying outside the curfew coming onto the market. By that I mean that such aircraft meet the requirements of the United States Federal Aviation Administration's regulations, as set out in paragraph 36, and also the International Civil Aviation Organisation's Annexe 16 on noise abatement procedures and the allowable noise from aircraft, be it fly-over lateral or take-off noise. The Airbus meets any criteria laid down in the world, particularly those of the FAA and the ICAO. We are not sure about the Boeing 767 as only a prototype is being flown, but it is equipped with engines similar to those of the Airbus-derivatives of the General Electric CF6. Therefore, there is no reason why we cannot expect it to meet the same noise criteria. Yet we have had in Brisbane a nauseating exercise to whip up people's emotions about what will happen if the new aircraft are allowed to fly between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m. The only way in which we can possibly keep air fares at a reasonable level is to obtain maximum utilisation of our aircraft. Our airlines buy aircraft which meet all the noise criteria set down by world bodies, yet the aim of this nauseating whipping up of people's emotions is to prevent those aircraft from doing precisely what they were designed to do.

If Trans Australia Airlines is not operating its five Airbuses between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m. we will have $300m worth of aircraft, that could be flying and raising revenue, sitting instead on the ground because of this ridiculous campaign. The same will be true of the five Boeing 767 aircraft when they are put into operation. It is pretty hard to put a cost on the loss in their case because Ansett Airlines of Australia bought them as part of a package, but we are looking at possibly $235m or $250m worth of aircraft-half a billion dollars worth of aircraft in all-sitting on the ground between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m. because of ridiculous complaints by people seeking short term political advantage. I venture to say that if a decibel meter reading were taken in Brisbane on either Nudgee Road or Kingsford-Smith Drive when an Airbus or a Boeing 767 was flying over on approach or take-off, the noise level would not register if a truck-of which there are many on those roads-were also passing at the time. There are many of them because both roads lead to industrial parts of Brisbane. What I am saying is that more traffic noise around that airport would be generated by heavy trucks going about their ordinary work than would be generated by either of those aircraft in their normal duties.

In any case, there would be no reason, other than extreme wind conditions, why during the hours of darkness the aircraft could not come in over Moreton Bay in Brisbane and over Botany Bay in Sydney. As I said, for the sake of short term political advantage the campaign to which I referred has been whipped up. The sooner the Government bites the bullet on this and gets use out of those aircraft so that we can keep our air fares as low as possible and the airlines can have a proper return on their investment the better off we will be. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate, including the Opposition, for its support of the Air Navigation (Charges) Amendment Bill. I acknowledge some of the points made during the debate. Senator Gietzelt made one or two points in relation to the recovery rate of charges and increases in charges over the years. He was right in acknowledging the fact that each year the rate of increase has risen. I suppose that in general terms that reflects the gradual development and growth of the industry over the years. In the early 1960s and the late 1950s one might have described the industry as being in its infancy. We can expect the industry as it develops to be in a stronger position and more able to meet the charges. Applying a rough rule of thumb, I think it is fair to say that the operations of the airlines and their continuing growth each year justify the approach to cost recovery that has been adopted.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Thomas, during his remarks-I was glad to learn that he is not opposing the legislation-acknowledged that fundamentally this legislation follows the user pays principle. He asked when the independent inquiry into air fares would be established. I understand that the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) announced yesterday that within the next two to three weeks an announcement would be made concerning the establishment of a committee to inquire into air fares. Senator Thomas mentioned also in his general comments on difficulties concerning air fares the Price Waterhouse Associates report and, in particular, the report of the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares. The Minister has announced that the Government will refer both the Holcroft report and the Price Waterhouse report to the independent air fares committee, when it is established, to consider when it conducts its first cost allocation review. Of course, those reports reflect different philosophies. No doubt the issues to which Senator Thomas addressed himself will be picked up and discussed by that committee at the appropriate time.

One particular matter Senator Thomas mentioned was the system whereby the charges applying to flights between Perth and Melbourne-I think he mentioned also flights between Perth and Sydney-include a loading for navigation costs incurred around Adelaide; that is, that part of the costs incurred in relation to air navigation services in Adelaide is incorporated in the total costs for those routes. I think Senator Thomas will acknowledge that, notwithstanding the fact that aircraft flying direct between Perth and Melbourne and Perth and Sydney do not land in Adelaide, they have contact with navigational aids in Adelaide. Consequently, charges for that service should be part of the costs incurred in running those flights.

Senator Haines addressed her remarks most particularly to the general aviation sector. One or two points need to be made in respect of that area. She argued that general aviation, because of its unique operation in outback areas and the services it provides in farming areas and certain developing areas of Australia, ought to be given special consideration in respect of air navigation charges. I think it is fair to say that that has been taken into account by the Government in assessing its approach and, indeed, the figures stand up to examination. Total air navigation costs within Australia amount to $262.2m and the general aviation sector's estimated share of those costs is $102.6m. I understand that has been calculated on the basis of a formula which has been agreed upon by the industry and the Government. On that calculation, general aviation's total share of air navigation costs is about 40 per cent.

We acknowledge that recovery of air navigation charges in the general aviation sector in 1980 was only of the order of 16.4 per cent. Accordingly, there has been a very substantial under-recovery in the general aviation sector's share of costs compared with the charges made to the industry generally. That is a very fair point to make in relation to Senator Haines's remarks. Furthermore, no increases have been made in the charges incurred during 1980. The last increase in respect of general aviation occurred in 1979. Since that time there has been an increase in the consumer price index of approximately 20 per cent. I repeat that those costs are allocated according to use of facilities and they are based on principles with which the industry, including the general aviation sector, has in general terms agreed.

Senator Collard showed his usual grasp of problems and of the difficulties within the air travel industry. He brought to our attention some significant problems with which he is closely associated. His remarks were very valuable and the Government notes the points he made, particularly those in relation to noise at Brisbane Airport. We acknowledge that a great deal of scaremongering about that problem is carried on in various places. The Government thanks the Senate for its support of the legislation and wishes the Bill a speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we are debating the first reading stage of this legislation I take the opportunity to reply to some of the comments made by Senator Messner in answer to an interjection made by me in the course of his reply to a question asked by Senator Foreman. Senator Messner is reported on page 499 of Senate Hansard of 8 September as having said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that Senator Foreman would recognise that the roots of the housing problem in South Australia do not stem from the imposition of any sales tax on building materials.

Of course, we know the present ills do not stem from those sales tax impositions as yet because, if the Government has its way, they will not be imposed until 1 January next year. Then we will really feel the adverse effects which will compound the problems which are being experienced in the building industry in South Australia at present. I interjected on Senator Messner and said:
No, they stem from the administration-or the maladministration-of the Tonkin Government.
Senator Messner said:

They certainly stem from the Dunstan and Corcoran governments in South Australia for many years previous. Senator McLaren would have to acknowledge that, as I know he is already fully aware of this problem. We all know that the major difficulties in housing in South Australia occurred in the period 1977-78 due to the very poor planning policies of the Dunstan Labor Government in South Australia at that time.

They were Senator Messner's words. Of course, he has learned a good lesson from Senator Carrick over the years in this place because every time this Government runs into problems Senator Carrick parrots the old saying: 'Oh well, it was the fault of the Whitlam Government'. The Tonkin Government has been in office in South Australia for two years and things are getting worse and worse in every avenue one looks at, as I will explain in the course of my remarks. It ill becomes Senator Messner to try to get Mr Tonkin off the hook by blaming a previous administration.

TALK.START.PARA: —They would be wiped out like the Liberals in New South Wales.

—My colleague Senator Sibraa says that if we were to go to an election in South Australia now the Liberal Party would be annihilated just as it was in New South Wales last Saturday. It is clearly evident that the general electors in the Commonwealth are fed up to the back teeth with the maladministration of Liberal governments. The South Australian Government will get its answer. The proof of the pudding will be in the eating because the people of South Australia are suffering. The people in New South Wales were not willing to overturn the Wran Government and opt for a government which could not manage the country's affairs. We have no better illustration of the way in which Australia as a whole is being mismanaged by the present Government than what is happening today in the other chamber where three Ministers are under severe attack from the Opposition for the way in which they have been carrying on and meddling in the affairs of the nation. They have clearly shown that they do not have the capabilities to run the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to deal particularly with the situation in South Australia. I remind Senator Messner that on 14 November 1979 during a speech I made on income tax legislation I warned the Senate and everybody else who cared to take any notice of the very things that are happening now under the Tonkin Liberal Government. It is again a case, as I often say in this chamber, of people being forewarned but not taking any notice. The Tonkin Government's chickens have come home to roost because it has made many promises which it has not been able to fulfil. I refer to a speech which is reported at page 2279 of Hansard of 14 November in which I quoted from an article which appeared in the local Adelaide Press. The article stated:
South Australia's business establishment will today close its anti-Labor election campaign after spending $100,000, according to figures from the Bureau of Statistics.
I went on to say:
The article, which was written for the Australian by its economist, Des Keegan, continues:
The whole campaign was prepared by Ogilvy and Mather, the multinational advertising group.

Its sponsors were the Chamber of Commerce and Industry SA Inc., the Master Builders Association of SA Inc., the Printing and Allied Trades Employers Federation of SA Region, the Retail Traders Association of SA Inc., the South Australian Chamber of Commerce Inc., and the South Australian Employers Federation Inc. The organisations set out to spend $100,000, with the help of a multinational advertising company, to discredit, the Corcoran Labor Government.

What do we find? A large full page advertisement appeared in the Advertiser just the other day. It was paid for by anonymous people and points out all the good things that the Premier of South Australia has done. These people are so proud of Mr Tonkin that they were not prepared to put their names to the advertisement. However, these people were prepared to put their names to the advertisement which was designed to get rid of the Corcoran Labor Government. The South Australian Leader of the Opposition has pointed out that there is no substance in many of these things that are being claimed. The advertisement is headed 'A few timely reminders that the record is solidly impressive.' The advertisement then displays a photograph of Premier Tonkin, no doubt sitting up in the Cabinet room in the State administration building in Adelaide. The Premier must have allowed someone into his office to take this photograph of him. The advertisement states:
Two great years of steady achievement.
But when we look at the bottom of the page to find out who organised the advertisement we find the words:
This message prepared and paid for by a large group of proud, confident South Australians.

How proud they are! They are like people who do not sign their names to letters they send to newspaper editors. That is how proud they are. Mr Tonkin must be very worried. I heard one comment on a news service in South Australia that he would take some action against these people because they used an unauthorised photograph. But I have seen nothing in the printed media that he is complaining about this.
Let me now draw the attention of the Senate to some of the things claimed in the advertisement.The advertisement states:
February 1980
Government establishes the State Development Council to advise on potential investment in the State.

To set up that Council the State Government had to knock over the industry assistance organisation which had beeen operating for years with great benefit to industry in South Australia. The Government threw this organisation out the door because it was the brainchild of the Dunstan Government and established something else in its place. That is nothing to be proud of because this change is not achieving anything. The Nationwide program pointed out last night that people are leaving South Australia in their thousands because small businesses are going broke and there are no jobs for young people. As a result people are flooding out of the State. Of course, Mr Tonkin said that if he were elected he would establish the State development council to stop the exodus of South Australian citizens from South Australia. But he has done the reverse. He has increased that exodus and people are leaving in their droves. The advertisement also stated:
March 1980
Government re-organises London Agent-General's Office, placing greater emphasis on trade and investment.

That is a complete failure because South Australia would be booming if there were a greater emphasis on trade and investment. But, of course, business people are leaving the State in their thousands. So the Agent-General's Office is costing South Australian taxpayers money but it is doing absolutely nothing for us. Further on, the advertisement states:
May 1980
Roxby Downs $50m exploratory shaft and feasibility studies.

Nothing yet has eventuated from those studies. Those promises are all pie in the sky. They are all promises that have not eventuated. They will not eventuate before Mr Tonkin is thrown onto the scrap heap, as Mr McDonald was last Saturday. The advertisement also states:
July 1980
This is another magnificent thing the Tonkin Government did-
Monarto land to be sold.

What is going to happen when the Monarto land is sold? Labor will want that land to settle people when it is returned to office in late 1982 or early 1983. We will have to buy it back at an enormous price because Mr Tonkin is going to give it away to his friends as he has done with a lot of the land in the Land Commission which was set up by the Dunstan Government with the support of the Whitlam Government. The advertisement also states:
October 1980
Agreement reached on granting of Land Rights to the Pitjantjatjara people.

Who introduced that legislation into the Parliament? It was none other than a Labor government under Mr Dunstan. Mr Tonkin has the temerity to claim that it is his legislation. All the legislation was prepared and ready to go through and all he did was put it through the Parliament. He cannot lay any legitimate claim to initiating that legislation. The advertisement states:
Joint Federal/State investigation into development potential of the Iron Triangle Area.

What has been found? What is there to boast about in looking at the development potential? We all know what the potential is. Mr Tonkin's friends have not said in this advertisement that the Fraser Liberal Government closed down the most viable and the greatest employer of labour at Whyalla-the shipyards. The Government let it go to rack and ruin and now Mr Tonkin is boasting about what he is doing for industry and investment in the Iron Triangle. The advertisement also states:
Government takes court action to oppose Irrigation Licences on N.S.W. rivers in an attempt to preserve River Murray water quality.

What a lot of nonsense! I have not had time to read the article appearing in today's Advertiser or to digest its contents properly. That point is completely rebutted by the New South Wales Minister responsible for the inquiry New South Wales has had. We all know what happened to the last Liberal Premier in South Australia when he ran an election campaign on the issue of water. He was annihilated. That was Mr Hall. He negotiated the Dartmouth agreement. There is nothing in the agreement about water quality for South Australia. All it mentioned was quantity. Recently I asked Senator Carrick: On how many occasions has South Australia not received its water entitlement since the signing of the River Murray Waters Agreement? Senator Carrick answered that it has been on only one occasion-in the season of 1944-45. So we have almost always received our water entitlement even if the quality is not all that it ought to be.

Last week I took the opportunity of bringing from South Australia on behalf of the Mobilong Rotary Club two cartons of River Murray water. I sent them around Parliament House. I hope that every member of parliament got a sample. I have heard all sorts of remarks since about the use the water was put to. I hope that this initiative of the Mobilong Rotary Club will at last get this Government off its backside and make it do something about the quality of the River. In the short time we were in government we set up the River Murray working party to look at the quality of the River Murray water. What has the Government done about that since? It has brought legislation into this Parliament providing for the expenditure of $200,000 over five years on water resources. From the last figures I looked at-and the time has nearly expired-about $130,000 of that money has still not been expended. What is the Government doing? It is doing absolutely nothing. In order for the Government to spend that money the States have to come to the party on a dollar for dollar basis. If they are not prepared to put a dollar in they get nothing from the Federal Government. I am reliably informed that the Government that has taken most advantage of that legislation by doing something about water quality is the New South Wales Labor Government. It is far ahead of the government of any other State. I have to admit that it is far ahead of the Government of my State of South Australia.

It was not my intention to talk about the River Murray today because it is a subject on its own. The only reason I have referred to it is that Mr Tonkin is claiming as one of his great achievements that he has taken court action to oppose irrigation licences on New South Wales rivers.

TALK.START.PARA: —So he should.

—What has anything the New South Wales Labor Government or any other government does got to do with South Australia? I add for Senator Thomas's information that he ought to have a look-I am sure he has-at the report of the River Murray working party and read the remarks of the previous Liberal Government in New South Wales. He will find the same recommendations and the same things being advocated as the Wran Labor Government has carried out. There has been no change. There has been only a change in government, but no change of policy. The point is that under the Commonwealth Constitution no State can interfere with another State's rights in relation to water. It is up to each State to look after its own water rights. I can well imagine what would happen if the river ran the other way, from South Australia. We in South Australia would be getting criticisms from the New South Wales or Victorian governments saying that we were not giving those States good quality water. They would be told: 'Mind your own business. You are getting your entitlement under the River Murray Waters Agreement and that is what you will get'. That is what we have always received in South Australia. Talking about quality, it took the initiative of the Whitlam and Dunstan Labor governments to set up the filtration plants in Adelaide. Under previous Liberal governments we had terrible water. At least a big percentage of the people now living in Adelaide and using reticulated water have good quality water through the initiative and the moneys provided by the Whitlam and Dunstan governments. The advertisement goes on to refer to November 1980. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Government establishes the Italian Earthquake Relief Fund to assist victims of the devastation in Italy. The Government donated $45,000 to the Fund.

Any government would do that in a time of disaster. One has only to cast one's mind back to the cyclone in Darwin. What did the Labor Government do? We provided all the money that was required to rehabilitate Darwin. I hate to think what the situation would have been if we had had a penny-pinching Liberal government in office in Canberra. Half of Darwin would still be in ruins. Yet this man's nameless supporters are claiming that he has done wonders for the State because he has given away $45,000 of the taxpayers' money. Of course, any other government would have done that and would not have boasted about it in a full-page advertisement like this. The people who put in this advertisement were no doubt put up to it by Mr Tonkin, but he does not want to own them. The advertisement goes on to state:
State Government granted powers to appeal against lenient court sentences.

Nobody objects to that. That is nothing wonderful. We amended legislation on legal matters all the time we were in government. People have to remember that during the reign of office of any Labor government in South Australia Labor never had the numbers in the Legislative Council. Much of our very good legislation which would have been of benefit to the South Australian citizens was rejected, amended or mutilated in some fashion by the Liberal dominated Council. The same applies to our legislation introduced in this place between 1972 and 1975. It was mutilated, rejected and let to lie in the Parliament for months on end. The present Government would not even debate the legislation. Yet we are accused of not doing these things in South Australia. The opinion polls now show a different picture from what this advertisement states. It refers to March 1981, after mentioning the same matter under the heading of October 1980, and states:
Legislation ratifying the Pitjantjatjara Land Rights Agreement approved by State Parliament.

Of course, the Labor Party started that too. In the main it was its legislation. It introduced it. I could go on talking about these things but the matter I am concerned about is that a State Premier has to resort to a method such as this-using anonymous people to put advertisements in a newspaper. Why does he not have the courage to put his name to the advertisement? We know that the advertisement was put in that newspaper in answer to the advertisement put in a few days previously by the Australian Labor Party in that State. The Australian Labor Party had the courage to put its name to all the terrible things it said Mr Tonkin was doing. We were not afraid. We did not want to hide behind anonymity in our advertisement. We were quite prepared to stand up to take responsibility for the placing of the advertisement in the newspaper. I refer to the advertisement which brought forth this anonymous advertisement. That advertisement stated:
A birthday message for the Tonkin Government . . . two wasted years.
The anonymous advertisement states:
Two Great Years of steady achievement.
We have hit the nail on the head in referring to two wasted years. The people of South Australia realise that. Our advertisement goes on to state:
Two years ago the Liberals promised to 'get South Australia moving again'. The Liberals promised to create more jobs . . .
But now we have the worst unemployment in Australia.

I point that out on most Wednesdays in the Senate when I give a notice of motion. Unfortunately, we have the highest unemployment of any State. We have a greater exodus of citizens from our State than any other State. Our advertisement goes on to state:
The Liberals promised to slash taxation . . .
But now we have massive increases in State charges, including electricity, water, sewerage, hospital bills plus bus, tram and train fares.

Why has Mr Tonkin had to do all those things? Because he made a rash promise at election time that he would abolish succession duties and gift tax. He now finds himself down the drain to the tune of about $30m because of the promises we admit that he honoured. But who did they benefit? Only the people in the wealthy, capitalistic section of South Australia. They are the people who benefited from those promises he has honoured. Who is paying the piper? The pensioners, the unemployed, every person who has to ride on a bus, every person who has to pay rent, every person who switches on an electric light and every person who uses water, whether to drink, to wash or to do laundry. They are the unfortunate people who are paying the piper for the promises made by a Liberal Government to satisfy the wishes of its wealthy friends. We then say in our advertisement:
The Liberals promised to get business on its feet . . .
But now we have record business bankruptcies.

I refer anyone who is interested to some of the statements put out by Mr Hurford, the honourable member for Adelaide, who is our spokesman on business affairs. He lists figures put out by the statisticians-not our people-demonstrating that South Australia has had a record number of bankruptcies in the last two years under the Liberal Tonkin Government. We further go on in the advertisement:
The Liberals promised to improve health and education . . .
But they've scrapped free hospital care, and school cutbacks threaten our greatest resource, our children.

Of course, the Liberals have never had any consideration for the health of the nation or for those people who cannot afford to pay. We know how they have scrapped the Medibank scheme. After many promises by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) that Medibank would not be interfered with, it no longer exists. We cannot take notice of any promise that a Liberal might make to try to win office. The proof of the pudding is in the eating; the promises are never carried out. So far as the schools are concerned, we know that the State Minister of Education in South Australia is in diabolical trouble. Even under the last South Australian Budget, another 300 teachers will be sacked. That, if nothing else, is a fair admission that young people are leaving the State. The Minister uses the argument, when we complain about the situation, that the children are not there to fill the schools. Why are they not there? It is because their mums and dads have had to leave the State and seek jobs elsewhere. That is all because of the maladministration of the Tonkin Government.

We know now that there is no free hospitalisation in South Australia. The present Minister of Health, Jennifer Adamson, has scrapped the agreement, which should have run until 1985, entered into by the Whitlam and Dunstan governments to safeguard the interests of people in South Australia who could not afford to pay costly hospital bills. That agreement has gone by the board, and everyone now is forced to join a private health insurance organisation because they cannot afford to pay the hospital fees. That is another broken promise. The advertisement then says:
Labor left office with a healthy Budget surplus.
Now State finances are in a mess. Even Dr Tonkin has been forced to admit that South Australia is 'sick'.

Those are his own words. I have a cutting from the Australian newspaper of 9 September in which he states that, and we also have transcripts of radio interviews he did in which he admitted that the State is sick. Who caused the sickness? It was no one else but Dr Tonkin. Last Wednesday I gave notice of a motion stating that the only way we can cure this sickness is for Mr Tonkin to abdicate and call in a team of specialists to treat the patient, led by none other than the capable administrator, Mr John Bannon, the Leader of the Opposition. The sooner these specialists are cadled in the sooner the patient, South Australia, will get out of its sick bed and return to a better economy. This advertisement was printed before the Budget came down; the situation is even worse now. We went on to say:
Today Dr Tonkin will deliver his black birthday Budget. Make sure there are no more unhappy returns.

I assure Senator Messner that, despite the fact that he joins with his leader in this place in trying to allocate blame for all the ills, whether ills brought about by the Federal Administration or by the Tonkin Administration, that will not get him off the hook in South Australia the next time we have an election. If Senator Messner has any clout at all or any pull with Mr Tonkin, in the interests of all who live in South Australia he ought to go to Mr Tonkin and say that he is aware of those facts and that Senator McLaren has really emphasised the point that the State is sick. I agree with Mr Tonkin. Let him go to the people and let the electors decide so that we in South Australia can get a dose of the proper medicine.

The other thing to which I wish to refer concerns the high unemployment figures, and I want to direct some criticism at the daily Press on this matter. During the meeting of the Estimates committee, I think yesterday, we discussed the estimates for the Australian Bureau of Statistics. I asked the Bureau whether it could put out a Press release, authorised by it giving the facts about unemployment. I will refer only to South Australia because that is the State in which I am vitally interested. In publishing the unemployment figures for the month of August, on Friday, 11 September, the Canberra Times says that South Australia had an increase in unemployment of 1,200. However, if we look at the Liberal bible in South Australia to see how the Liberals interpret the ABS figures, under the by-line of Brett Bayly, we find the headline 'Fewer jobless than last year'. Bayly goes on to say that there were 100 fewer jobless, 100 fewer persons seeking employment in South Australia, in August of this year than there were last year.

I got quite upset about that and I rang the Australian Bureau of Statistics to ask for an explanation. The chap I spoke to said: 'Senator, unfortunately they are both right'. The ABS figures, which were printed in the Canberra Times, gave two monthly figures for those people seeking full time employment, with 1,200 more people seeking full time employment in South Australia during August than there were in July. There was a decrease of 100 when the two figures were lumped together, as Brett Bayly did. He did not explain that he had lumped the two together-I do not blame him; it was probably the editor of the paper who tinkered with his statement-and that those seeking part time employment were added to those seeking full time employment. Any sensible person knows that those registered for part time employment must have some other form of income. They might be on superannuation or on a pension, or they might be housewives whose husbands have jobs. They cannot really be classed as people who are legitimately unemployed; that is, breadwinners who are seeking jobs.

Another matter I raise every year in the consideration of the estimates for the Bureau of Statistics is that, because of the way the Bureau compiles its figures, those figures are most misleading. They are the figures this Government chooses to use as the legitimate figures because it has done away with publishing the figures compiled by the Commonwealth Employment Service, that is, the actual number of people who are registered as unemployed. How does the ABS compile its figures? It compiles them by doing random sample tests. An interviewer will knock on a door and ask the person who comes to the door to answer a certain number of questions. If the person questioned admits that he or she was employed for one hour of any one week, that person is not classed as being unemployed. That is why we get a fictitious figure. The actual unemployment figures for Australia, particularly in my own State, are much higher than some of the published figures. Unfortunately, that is how these figures are arrived at by this Fraser Government, whose policies Mr Tonkin boasted he fully supported during the 1979 election campaign. I will bet that many times he has rued the day he admitted that in his policy speech. I do not have much time for the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr Viner), and my estimation of him drops every time I hear him give an interpretation of unemployment figures. I have never heard anyone manipulate figures to suit his own cause better than Mr Viner can. He is a past master at it, and that is about the only thing at which he is a past master. He cannot find jobs for young people.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is nearly past.

—I know he is under sentence in the other place today. All members might get a notice in the next day or two to attend the funerals of three ex-Ministers. There will be a long wake, but not too many people on this side of the chamber will be worrying about that. No matter who is put in their places to do the jobs they have been trying to do, they could not do a worse job. No three who could be picked from the back bench of the Liberal Party could do a worse job than that done by the three Ministers who are under attack today. As I said when the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations report on Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd was tabled the other day, had the Whitlam Government been in power Mr Whitlam would not have dilly-dallied, trying to protect those Ministers. He would have acted immediately and they would have been axed. That is not the case with Mr Fraser. He is propped up by the National Country Party and he is dead scared, scared out of his wits, about bringing down the axe on the two National Country Party Ministers involved. He might have second thoughts about that after the New South Wales election results are known and Mr Punch overthrows the Liberal Party leader as the official Leader of the Opposition. Then, I am afraid, a lot of the fluff will hit the fan and there will be trouble for the Liberal Party, particularly in this sphere. The Party has trouble in the other States, and it will get worse.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning back to the full-page advertisement that appeared in the Adelaide Advertiser recently, Mr Bannon has posed the question: Who paid for that advertisement? We want to know who paid for it. We know who paid for the political advertisements which appeared prior to the election in 1975. Those people, although they were quite wrong in what they said, at least had the courage to admit who they were when they published those advertisements. But the people who published this advertisement, trying to prop up Mr Tonkin, do not have the courage of their convictions. People who write anonymous letters or insert anonymous advertisements in the papers should never be given any credence. We know that a lot of the advertisements that we saw previously were authorised by Mr Buick of Kangaroo Island. I am assured by a pretty reliable source from there that Mr Buick did not have the money to pay for these advertisements. Perhaps when we get back into government we may be able to have an inquiry to see who in fact paid for those advertisements. It certainly was not Mr Buick. We might be able to find out who paid for the big advertisement which appeared in today's paper and whether the State emblem has been misused by a group of anonymous people trying to prop up a sick Premier who is leading a sick State. They are not my words; they are the words that the Premier is quoted as saying in the newspaper.

In the speech that I made on 14 November 1979 I predicted quite a number of things that would happen under the Tonkin administration. I will not take up the time of the Senate this afternoon by reading them. In that speech I quoted a lot of statistics. They were not my figures. They were figures which had been compiled by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. I would recommend to Senator Messner that he have a look at them. After he has read that speech and analysed those statistics, perhaps next time he is asked a question in the Senate, or I interject, he might curb his tongue and not try to blame the Corcoran Government for the ills of South Australia.

This is the second time that Senator Messner has been caught out. A couple of years ago, in reply to one of the reports that I put out on a regular basis, I received a letter from him complaining that the figures that I quoted were not correct. It took Senator Messner three months to write to me after he had received my report. I took just three minutes to reply to him. I gave him the source of my figures. Where did those figures come from? They came from the Liberal Government Budget which was put down in this chamber. I have not had another letter from Senator Messner saying that my figures were wrong. I do not know who did his research. I take it he did it himself, because he is a qualified accountant. When I received his reply I was somewhat startled to think that my research may have been off the beam. I had another look and I saw that we got all the figures out of the Budget Papers. I wrote and told Senator Messner that and he has never again said that any of my figures are crook. I am sure that when he reads this speech he will not be able to say that my quotations today are crook.

Once again I have brought to the attention of the Senate the problems that exist in South Australia. I have explained that it is high time that the present incumbent of the office of Premier in South Australia stood down and allowed the State to be run by the team of experts who ran it successfully for 10 years, and who will do so again. I hope that I do not have to speak about this matter again until my notices of motion come up for debate. We will deal with them individually. At that stage I will give details of all of the ills which exist in the State of South Australia.

I raise one other matter. I intended to raise this matter in the adjournment debate but now that this legislation has been introduced out of the blue I will take this opportunity of raising it. I refer to the railway system in South Australia. I have stood up many times and criticised the Australian National Railways. I still refer to it as the Australian National Railways, despite the fact that the Commissioners, in their wisdom, engaged a firm of consultants, at a cost of $409,000, who advised them to change the name, to drop the name 'railways'. Unless a photograph of a freight car or a locomotive is included in advertisements nobody knows what the words 'Australian National' mean.

I was very disturbed to read in the Advertiser of Tuesday, 15 September, an article by Stuart Innes headed 'More private rail systems predicted'. That prediction was made at a seminar by Mr D. P. Smith, chief engineer of Australian National Railways. If we do away with government-owned and run railways and hand them over to Australian enterprise, it will be a sad day for Australia.

I can well remember during the war years when I was in Western Australia in the Army. There was a private railway from Midlands to Walkaway. Running on it was what was known as the square wheeled train. There was never any guarantee that it would reach its destination. It was a dilapidated old train run by private enterprise. Senator Coleman, a Western Australian, would know of that train. I had to travel on that train on many occasions. I tell the Senate now that one could not get a wink of sleep on it. That is what will happen to our railways.

The problem that I want to raise now is one which was brought to my attention today by the president of the Save the Victor Harbour Railway Committee, Mr Tillbrook. He rang me today. He is very concerned that Australian National Railways are about to dispose of 19 of the 25 steel carriages known as steel cars that are left in the State. They are used mainly on the Victor Harbour line to go to Barossa Valley when seminars and conventions are held. They attract a lot of revenue by way of tourist money. Australian National Railways, for some reason, have decided to dispose of 19 of these cars. There will be only six left in South Australia. One will be stationed at Mount Gambier, one at Port Pirie of Port August and four will be left in Adelaide. A promise was made some time ago to Mr Dean Harvey, president of the Railway Historical Society, that the Society would be allowed to buy six of these cars for about $2,500. The Railway Historical Society was going to restore them.
