SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commence my speech by reading one paragraph of the Budget Speech delivered in this place on 18 August 1981. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: At present, stamp duties in the Australian Capital Territory apply to a narrower range of instruments and transactions than those in the States. Moreover, most of the rates applying in the Territory have not been altered since they were introduced in 1969 and are generally lower than those in the States. Accordingly, we have decided to bring the range and levels of Australian Capital Territory stamp duties more into line with those of the States.

In passing I would say that to some extent I would not regard that as a satisfactory basis for running any enterprise, but there are some other matters which flow from it if in fact that is the criterion for government in the Australian Capital Territory. The same principles should apply in other places. I look forward to the Treasurer (Mr Howard) bringing in the appropriate amendments to legislation which will enable this to happen.
I refer to the States Grants (Home Care) Act 1961, which in the entitlement states:
An Act to grant Financial Assistance to the States in relation to the provision of certain Home Care and other Welfare Services by States, Local Governing Bodies and Community Welfare Organizations
Under the definition of 'home care service' it states:
. . . means a service in the nature of housekeeping or other domestic assistance to persons in their homes;
Section 5 of the Act states:

For the purposes of this Part, the Minister may, at the request of a participating State, approve a scheme conducted, or to be conducted, by the State, a local governing body, a community welfare organization or a joint body for the provision of a home care service wholly or mainly for aged persons in respect of which that State proposes to incur expenditure.

We have an emergency housekeeper service in the Australian Capital Territory which provides an excellent service to this community and which is funded from the community welfare grant to the extent of $246,000 a year. If we were to share, as we ought to be able to share, and as is outlined in the statement I quoted from the Budget, this Act should be amended to include not only States but also the Australian Capital Territory so it can participate in these grants for the purpose of at least financing some of its emergency housekeeper service. Section 8 of the States Grants (Home Care) Act states:
For the purposes of this Part, the Minister may, at the request of a participating State, approve a project for-
(a) the provision of an approved welfare service-
(i) by a senior citizens' centre;

Again, the Australian Capital Territory is not included and thus senior citizens centres in the Australian Capital Territory cannot share as those in the States do. We are not asking for anything special for the Australian Capital Territory. Given that all things are to be equal under the Australian Capital Territory stamp duty legislation, we are merely asking that they be equal under the States Grants (Home Care) Act. But that is not all; it does not end there.

Recently there was some publicity and certainly a great deal of joy in the community because the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman), together with the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr Viner), had reinstated a group apprenticeship scheme. The Master Builders Association of the Australian Capital Territory will now be able to run an apprenticeship scheme which is very necessary in the Territory. An amount of $45,000 has been allocated to that scheme for the current year. Given the contribution to similar schemes in the States, that is a very worthwhile donation. It is a scheme, as I said, which already exists in the States. But at least Victoria and New South Wales provide a rebate on the payroll tax that the Master Builders Association would have to pay on the money that it pays by way of wages to the apprentices under the scheme. I ask the Treasurer: What about the Australian Capital Territory? Why can the Master Builders Association in the Australian Capital Territory not receive the same benefits so that the money for apprentices in this area can be used particularly for that purpose?

All this leads me to say that the reference to the Commonwealth Grants Commission for a study of the finances of the Australian Capital Territory is not only overdue; it is urgent. What contribution should the Commonwealth make to the municipal finances of the Australian Capital Territory? What areas of the Australian Capital Territory are truly national, what areas are of a State nature and what are local government areas? The Canberra Development Board was criticised recently by a member in another place. Mr Lusher said that the Commonwealth ought not to be spending money on promoting the Board. That is nonsense. The Federal Government in this area is spending money that would be spent by a State government in any other place but the Australian Capital Territory. Certainly in Mr Lusher's State of New South Wales considerable sums of money are spent by the State Government promoting the State and attracting business and industry to it. We merely ask that we have a fair share of money for the same purpose.

To a large extent the costs we are paying for in the Australian Capital Territory have been caused by the fact that the city has been planned for a population much larger than at present. That is not unreasonable, but it is a factor that needs to be taken into account when assessing the sorts of matters that the Grants Commission, I hope, will look at quite soon.

It was stated recently that the ACT is a tax haven. That assertion is not factually sustainable. It may have been in this one small area of stamp duty which has now been corrected. But in other respects it is not and, in fact, the position is quite the reverse.

It is known that the Commonwealth does not pay rates, not only in the ACT but anywhere. But the impact of that fact here is much greater than in other places. I understand that ratable property in the ACT is approximately 25 per cent of the total. I gather the Fremantle City Council was particularly upset two or three years ago when it found that its ratable property amounted to only 51 per cent of its total land. In addition to the national capital being designed for a much larger population than now exists-which means that we are paying for some facilities not being fully utilised-the works and services which have been developed here are, to a great extent; developed to a much higher standard than might have been the case but for the fact that this is the national capital and a place that we would hope that all Australians would be proud of.

What happens to the 2 per cent of income tax for local government which is collected from the citizens of the Australian Capital Territory but not paid to any municipal authority in the Australian Capital Territory? Approximately $3m is paid by the Commonwealth towards its share of what constitutes the municipal accounts but no accounting is made for this 2 per cent of income tax which we do not receive. In addition, local government gets money in some instances from its State. It can sell land and it collects the rates from its area.

There are other areas in which the ACT is dealt with differently from the States. For some reason the price of petrol is higher in Canberra than in Queanbeyan, which is only a very short distance away. When air fares went up, I think in April this year, as a result of the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares, fares with respect to Canbrra went up by 38 per cent. It is not with any pride that I relate that there was laughter on both sides of the House at that event when the national increase was only 7 per cent.

I understand that the rates in Canberra are calculated in a manner different from that of the States in that the pricing of land for rating purposes in Canberra includes the cost of head works whereas in the States the cost of head works is included in the rate structure. In a sense, one might say that in the Australian Capital Territory the costs of the head works are paid for twice.

I am not asking for any special payments to be made to Canberra but, given the quotation that I started my remarks with today-that stamp duties should be more in line with those of the States-I ask the Government to see that other adjustments are made to legislation, to see that at least these few matters I have mentioned today are also brought 'into line' with those of the States.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a number of issues in this first reading debate on money Bills. Most of them relate to Aboriginal affairs. I raise these matters in response to a directive that has been issued in Western Australia by the Minister for Police and Traffic, and Minister for Community Welfare, a letter from the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) relating to a film about Aboriginal land rights in Australia and, of course, another item in a recent issue of the Sunday Times relating to research which it is now no longer possible to carry out because of a directive by the Western Australian Minister, Mr Hassell.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer also to the situation that arises in respect of pastoral leaseholds in the north of Western Australia. Information which I have been given leads me to believe that a large number of white station holders are in fact ripping off the Australian taxpayer by Aboriginal communities which are living and working on their stations being paid only the unemployment benefit. I want to touch on the latest directive by the Western Australian Minister for Community Welfare, Mr Hassell, which was reported on in the Sunday Times on 2 August. The article states:
One historian claims he now cannot research the infamous Flying Foam Massacre of 1868-
That, incidentally, occurred in the Kimberleys in Western Australia-
in which more than 60 Aboriginals including children were allegedly killed by white settlers.
A new security restriction affects records held by the Community Welfare Department, the Aboriginal Affairs planning Authority, and the former Native Welfare Department.
Under the new policy, people seeking access to these records have to identify themselves, give their reason for seeking access, and provide the names of three referees.
Conditional approval is required for access to CWD records less than 30 years of age, but no clearance is necessary for files older than 30 years.
However, the conditions for seeking access apply in both cases.
The department says the security clampdown is necessary because some documents could cause embarrassment to living people or their families. The aim is to protect the privacy of the individual.

One of the researchers said that she failed to see how an event in the 1890s could embarrass the government of the day or living people. One of those who was anxious to see those closed files is an anthropologist and an artist who often paints Aboriginal figures. She spent three years researching Aboriginal traditions in the south-west and last year she found that the files of the Community Welfare Department had been closed. According to the newspaper article she said:
I wrote to seek access for my on-going research program. Their letters gave no reason for the ban and my work was delayed for six months.

Mr Deputy President, I think you will agree that it is a tragedy when researchers find that information exists but is not made available to them. It means that their time and resources have been wasted. As this researcher has said, for up to three years she has been researching this matter and now finds that she can no longer have access to those files. I think it is rather sad that it is presumed that we will cause embarrassment to living people. I wonder how much embarrassment can be caused. A person is not his or her father's or mother's keeper. I do not believe that people would start pointing fingers and say: 'This is what your family did'. If they did, is a person to be held responsible for what his or her family did?

Recently a film was shown in Parliament House. The Parliamentary Library was able to obtain for me the film entitled On Sacred Ground. At the beginning of that film, the narrator who was obviously Aboriginal says that he comes from a very prominent Western Australia family. I do not think his family would have been embarrassed by having seen that film. I do not think other families would have been caused any embarrassment if they had read in someone's research paper that their forebears had been responsible for doing certain things. It does not mean that they are responsible. It simply means that their forebears were not as enlighted or as intelligent, or that perhaps they lived in a more violent period.

I think the withholding of information indicates the attitude of the Western Australian Government and its fear that people will be able to pinpoint the attitudes that are expressed by the Government in a number of insidious ways. As the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting is coming up we find an awful lot of avenues for matters to be put under the carpet and hidden behind wardrobe doors. We are embarrassed because we do not necessarily treat in a proper manner the people of this country, the original Australians who happen to have skin of a colour different from our own. We are a little petrified that people all over the world may become aware of this if we speak out.

In one of those directives which came from the Minister for Community Welfare, Mr Hassell, he instructed his Director of the Department of Community Welfare, Mr Keith Maine, that all officers of the Community Welfare Department were to have no dealings whatsoever with the Kimberley Land Council, that it was not a recognised body. It seems to me a rather peculiar circumstance, given that we have recently had a World Council of Churches investigation into the treatment of Aborigines and given that the Western Australian Government refused to meet with the WCC and was very scathing in its remarks about the members of the World Council of Churches, that the Minister should pick this time to issue a further directive that could only antagnise an already dangerous situation as far as the Aboriginal people in Western Australia were concerned.

Honourable senators may not be aware of the fact that the Kimberley Land Council receives neither State nor Federal Government funding. It has never requested State Government funding and it has never requested Federal Government funding. It is funded by the World Council of Churches. It has made no secret of that fact. It is funded also by other human rights organisations. It has not made any secret of that fact either. The fact that it does not have either State or Federal funding does not mean that it is not representative of the people in the Kimberley. I do not know of one community in the Kimberley that is not associated with the Kimberley Land Council. Of course, I am referring to Aboriginal communities. The Kimberley Land Council has been extremely successful in a number of areas. I suppose that the definition of success depends entirely on the interpretation of the person who is using the word. I would say that the Council has been extremely successful in bringing to the attention of the people of Australia the abhorrent situation that arose in relation to Noonkanbah. It seems quite incredible for me to be standing in this place and speaking about Noonkanbah when one appreciates that although the situation occurred only a short time ago people appear to have forgotten what it was all about. I am curious about some of the things which Mr Hassell put in his directive and why he put them there. To me it is an invitation to have a fairly large and a fairly rapid turnover of members of the Community Welfare Department. For instance, Mr Hassell said:

If some officers cannot accept that it is their duty to carry out policy decisions of the government of the day, then they are free to tender their resignations and these will be accepted by the Government.
He also said:
. . . it is the responsibility of the officers of the Department of Community Welfare to deliver welfare services apolitically.

If a situation arose where an Aboriginal community in Western Australia determined that the Kimberley Land Council was truly representative of that community and asked it to approach the Community Welfare Department for assistance, it could be refused that assistance by the officers of the Department given the directive that has been issued by the Minister for Community Welfare. It appears to me that it is a rather arrogant reminder that most of those people who service the community through the Community Welfare Department should adopt an apolitical stance. I imagine that the nature of their tasks would be fairly widespread. In view of the isolation and remoteness of some parts of the Kimberleys it may not necessarily be opportune for them to obtain a directive from their immediate superior and it may be necessary for them to make decisions which could, under that directive, be seen to be political rather than apolitical. If one were to disagree or raise problems associated with a directive such as this it could be said to be political, but to agree silently to whatever the Minister demands could be seen to be apolitical. If the Minister's directive were carried out to the letter it could stop those officers of the Community Welfare Department from doing their job either apolitically or even properly.

I mentioned earlier that I wanted to speak about a situation that exists on some of the pastoral stations. I intend to raise it now but because time for debate this afternoon is limited I will in continuation at a later stage go into it in more depth. In this chamber on 10 September I said in the second reading debate on the Western Australian Aboriginals (Right to Electoral Enrolment) Bill introduced by my colleage Senator Peter Walsh that there had been an occasion when the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) was in the Kimberley region in the north of Western Australia where I had seen things that either he determined he would not see or he deliberately did not make time to go to see. I raised one issue that related to people at Halls Creek who were from the Nicholson Downs station. I mentioned that at the time I went there some 35 to 40 people, including young children and a couple of babies, had one canvas fly for shelter and were having a 40-gallon drum of fresh water delivered to them by the shire each day. Whilst attempts had been made to provide them with other shelter this had not been forthcoming from the various departments. I questioned the fact that while the Minister had been in the area he had not gone to see them.

It now appears that those people have moved to Ringers Soak where, honourable senators might recall, members of the community from Gordon Downs were sent last year because the white pastoral owner decided it was time for them to move off his leasehold. I went to see the people from Nicholson Downs. I was very disturbed at what I was told. For many years they had been working as station hands-stock hands on the station. They had not been paid wages but they had all been in receipt of unemployment cheques. There was on the station a store managed by the leaseholder or the manager in place of the landholder and their cheques were actually kept and the amount of money for the goods that were purchased was deducted from them. It seemed a little strange to me that at no time was any money left over to be handed to the people. One of the complainants informed me that he had received a cheque from the Department of Social Security for something like $1,000 and that the station manager had suggested to him that he did not want him to be carrying around that amount of money and that he would keep it on his behalf. The complainant did purchase some goods from the store-he admits to that-but when he went back to get his money he was told there was no money left in his account.

They are very serious accusations and I suggest in view of those and other complaints that have been received, not only by me but also by other members of parliament over many years, that if station owners in the north of Western Australia, and similarly in the Northern Territory and Queensland, are in actual fact using Aboriginal labour as stock hands and station hands and not paying the people cash money then there is good cause for some form of investigation. I really do not care whether the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) or the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs accepts the responsibility. But I do make the point that it is essential, given these latest circumstances, that an investigation take place fairly soon. We have seen the investigations that have taken place in other sections of our community. We have seen the investigations involving a group of Greek people in Sydney not so very long ago when it was thought they were defrauding the Department of Social Security; and this is exactly the same circumstance. There is no difference between the allegations that are being made now and the allegations that were made then. If in actual fact fraud against the Government has been taking place then it is time that the Department exposed that fraud and advised, simply by announcing that there will be an investigation, those landholders that in actual fact the Government is not prepared to use taxpayers' money as a form of providing cheap labour for pastoralists in any part of Australia. Mr Acting Deputy President, given the time I now seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 20 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Australian Government taken any steps pursuant to Article 6 of the Paris Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property Revised to protect State Emblems, Official Hallmarks and Emblems of Intergovernmental Organisations; if so, what steps have been taken and when; if not, does the Australian Government propose to take any such steps.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: It has been assumed that the honourable senator in fact intended to refer to Article 6ter of the Paris Convention, and this answer reflects that assumption.
The Government has taken steps pursuant to Article 6ter of the Paris Convention.

Sub-paragraph 3(a) of that Article provides inter alia that countries party to the Convention communicate to each of the other member countries, through the International Bureau of the World Intellectual Property Organisation (WIPO) the list of State emblems and official hallmarks which they desire to place under the protection of Article 6ter.

Similarly sub-paragraph 3(b) provides inter alia for intergovernmental organisations to communicate to each country party to the Convention through the International Bureau of WIPO, the emblems which they desire to place under the protection of Article 6ter.

By virtue of paragraph (g) of sub-section 29(1) of the Trade Marks Act 1955, the Registrar of Trade Marks is empowered to refuse registration of State Emblems, etc., notified by the International Bureau under the provisions of Article 6ter of the Paris Convention.
Further, sub-section 29(2) of the Trade Marks Act allows regulations to provide for prevention of the use as a trade mark of the State Emblems etc., in question.
These provisions have been in force since 1 August 1958.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 25 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware: (a) of Press reports describing the experiences of Australian tourist, Mr Gordon Parkes, who was jailed and mistreated by Bangkok police last July after being arrested and falsely charged with possession of heroin; (b) that a $10,000 bribe was demanded and received by Thai police before Mr Parkes was released and repatriated to Australia; and (c) that a senior Thai police officer, Captain Surajet, was subsequently despatched to Australia to interview Mr Parkes and that the Captain admitted that Mr Parkes had been 'criminally mistreated' and that a $2,000 bail bond would be immediately refunded and that the Thai police force would attempt to recover the $10,000 bribe.
(2) Has the $12,000 been refunded; if not, will the Government lodge a strong protest with the Government of Thailand and demand the refund of this money as a matter of urgency.

(3) Will the Government seek an assurance from the Government of Thailand that steps have been taken to curb illegal police activities and that such treatment of innocent Australian tourists is not permitted to occur again.
(4) Will the Government actively discourage Australian tourists from visiting that country and publish regular information bulletins to keep the public informed until the situation improves.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Yes.
(b) No.
(c) No. The Thai police official was returning to Thailand from New Zealand and it was arranged for him to undertake an investigation with the assistance of the Australian Federal Police.
As the Thai officials have not made available a copy of any report made by the police officer it is not known whether any admissions were made about the bail bond or the alleged bribe.

(2) Not as far as is known. Mr Parkes has not made contact with the Department of Foreign Affairs despite its approach to him. Until the Department is aware of all the circumstances of the alleged incident, no approaches to the Thai Government are contemplated. It is, of course, for Mr Parkes to decide upon any further action which he wishes to be taken in this matter.
(3) The Government will consider what action to take when it is in possession of all the facts.

(4) No. Many thousands of Australian tourists visit Thailand each year and because of one incident we should not seek to discourage such travellers. In a booklet 'Hints for Australian Travellers' issued with all new passports, intending travellers are warned that they are subject to the laws of the countries they visit, to respect the customs of these countries and to seek the assistance of consular officers overseas if they encounter difficulties.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 June 1981 (Hansard, page 2740) Senator Grimes asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the Program of Aids for Disabled People.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

All States and the Northern Territory were invited to participate in the operation of the Program of Aids for Disabled People (PADP) on the same basis, namely, in addition to meeting the cost of aids, the Commonwealth would provide a 15 per cent loading on the cost of aids issued as a handling charge.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 June 1981 (Hansard, page 2795) Senator Townley asked me, as Minister for Social Security, the following question without notice concerning the overseas payment of pensions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Is the Minister able to say how much the Australian Government pays overseas by way of pensions to people living overseas and how much is received into Australia on the reciprocal basis?

(2) As pensions are taxable in Australia, will the Minister consider taxing any pensions that are sent overseas at least at the base tax rate so that, if people are working and living in another country, they are not better off than Australian pensioners?
(3) Finally, is this whole matter of reciprocity of pensions being examined?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

(1) The expenditure overseas on pensions was $47.78m in 1980-81. This figure includes amounts paid under general portability provisions and under reciprocal agreements to Australian residents in the United Kingdom and New Zealand. It represents payments made to pensioners who left Australia permanently as well as payments to persons who are residing overseas on a temporary basis. It should be noted however that no record is available in respect of people overseas whose pensions continue to be paid in Australia by, for example, credit to a bank account.

Statistics relating to the value of overseas pensions brought to Australia by immigrants are not available. However, using information on income from overseas pensions supplied by pensioners, it is estimated that some 70,000 social security pensioners were also in receipt of overseas pensions at September 1980. The value of such overseas pensions was estimated to be in the order of $65 million in a full year. Of the pensioners receiving overseas pensions, some 58,000 had their overseas pension treated as income for pension purposes and some 12,000 benefiting under the reciprocal agreement on social security between Australia and Britain had their overseas pension directly deducted from the Australian pension.

(2) The Treasurer has advised that the present position is that pensions (other than exempt pensions) derived by non-residents from sources in Australia, are subject to tax in Australia, except where Australia has a comprehensive double taxation agreement with the country in which the non-resident resides which provides for the taxation of pensions in the country of residence of the recipient and exemption in the country of source.

However, Australia, like most if not all other countries, taxes non-residents only on income from sources in Australia, so that if the pension is the non-resident's only income from an Australian source, and the amount of the pension is below the level at which tax becomes payable in Australia ($4,195 for the 1981-82 income year), no Australian tax will be payable by the non-resident.

On the other hand, overseas pensioners would generally be liable to tax on the Australian pension in their home country, and so the question of whether they are better off from a tax viewpoint than Australian pensioners will depend on the tax laws of the country in which they reside, as well as on any other income they derive.

It will be appreciated from the foregoing that existing double taxation agreements which give sole taxing rights to the country in which the pensioner resides would prevent the adoption of the Senator's suggestion in relation to the countries concerned.

Adoption of the suggestion in relation to other countries would involve some significant changes in taxation of income flowing from Australia to non-residents. For example, it would mean taxing invalid pensions paid to persons under age pension age who reside overseas, while those paid to residents of Australia are exempt. It would also mean that a non-resident pensioner would be taxed on an Australian pension even though his or her total Australian income is below the tax threshold, whereas another non-resident deriving an equivalent amount of salary or wages, or rents, from sources in Australia, would not be subject to tax here.
Notwithstanding these comments, arrangements have been made to have the suggestion noted for consideration on the next occasion when this general issue is being considered.
(3) See Hansard (9 June 1981, page 2795).

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following in answer to the honourable senator's question:
In answer to Senator Button's question I refer him to a statement I released to the Press on 18 August 1980, entitled 'Premature Disclosure of Budget Information' in which I said, inter alia:

Having discussed the matter at length with the Secretary to the Treasury and other senior officials of my Department, I am as satisfied as one can be in such circumstances that the disclosure could only have come from my office, the Treasury or the Government Printer.
